description: Had a great dinner tonight! Service was great! Food was amazing! I can't wait to go back and try more things! My only qualm was that we ordered a nice bottle of wine that arrived very chilled and there was no ice bucket or way to maintain it chilled for us... They just just put it on the table and it quickly warmed up... They get 5 stars because I can't give them 4.5 stars and I'm not a complete a-hole. Small basics make a big difference.
author: David F.

description:
Came here with a party of 10 to celebrate my friend's birthday on a Saturday night. It was great because they gave us the booth and set up the tables nicely for us. They are known for placing freshly cut roses in a vase at each table, which was very classy by the way. The interior of the restaurant is very romantic and perfect for a conversation with that special someone. There are also pictures of various people who have eaten at the restaurant. We got here right around 6:30 but not everyone showed up yet. The host was very patient with us and let us wait until more of our friends arrived before we caved in and started ordering appetizers because we were hungry. I think the place is family owned because it looks like the father and son are the ones running the restaurant and working with the cooks in the back. 

The first thing that they give you is fresh bread. It is sooooo good and be careful because the bread is hot and will burn your hand. It is also hot enough to melt the butter they give you. They kept filling the basket of bread and I am so grateful they did because everyone loved it. 
For appetizers we ordered the Calamari Vinaigrette and Antipasto Misto. I'm always a fan of the antipasto and I highly recommended ordering it here, you won't be let down by the various selections of meats and cheeses. For the main course I had the Tortellini and it was freshly made in the kitchen. It paired great with the Peroni beer. I also had a sample of the veal and it was cooked very well but my friend didn't like the wine sauce that it was sauteed with. I, on the other hand, thought it was fine.

The restaurant noise level is very quiet but our loud friend amped up the volume and made everyone else in the restaurant talk louder. Good thing nobody gave us the awkward stare or told us to quiet down. It was so funny because the volume went up every time he talked.

We told the hostess that it was our friend's birthday so you know the usual tradition when that happens. They dimmed the lights, played happy birthday on the stereo, and came out with a big slice of tiramisu cake for the birthday boy. We all got a taste of it so you can tell it's really big and I do recommend it for dessert. 

I don't normally give 5 stars but when I do, it's for exceptional and extraordinary service. La Traviata gets all the stars for their atmosphere, food, service and most importantly, the dining experience.
author: Tim G.

description:
Our server Nadia, deserves 5 stars for sure. She was adorable, had good recommendations and knowledge of food and wine and was still friendly even though my date and I arrived right before closing :) 
For the price, cheap glasses of wine, free yummy fresh bread, and good pasta. Definitely a good spot. Ill come back for sure.
Great caprese salad and pesto pasta. 
Can't beat this place if you're craving Italian and in the mission area.
author: Kayla C.

description:
My boyfriend and I LOVE this place. The food is all really, really good. There's also delicious, freshly made bread (!!!) and the minestrone soup is excellent. I also love the veal parmesean (huge portion) and several of the chicken dishes (one in particular with cheese and prosciutto) are all divine. The price was pretty good, although we found some salads to be a bit expensive.

The decoration/atmosphere inside the restaurant certainly leaves a lot for improvement, it doesn't look like there has been any sort of update to the décor since the restaurant opened in the '70's.

If you care only about the taste of food and care less about the décor, this place is for you. Service was also good.
author: Farrah L.

description:
A dark and cozy Italian restaurant that's heavy on the warmth and light on the pretentiousness. It's the perfect date spot for couples looking for pasta without astronomical prices, snooty service or crazy wait times. My girlfriends and I enjoyed some classic Italian-American favorites like Linguine ai Funghi and Spaghetti Carbonara, both of which were delicious. The wine list was impressive and we split a bottle of Tuscan pinot grigio that didn't break the bank.

The really fun thing about the restaurant besides the kitschy decor is the fact that if it's your birthday, they like to do a good, ol' fashioned birthday singalong, complete with dimmed lights and loud voices. It's embarrassing and entertaining all at once. Oh, and the slice of tiramisu you're given is delicious and big enough to for 4 people to share. Service is as warm and friendly as the restaurant itself.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Forget about all North Beach italian restaurants and come to this cozy little place in the Mission St. 

This authentic italian place is decorated with portraits from 70's, 80's of the family, I assume. Birthdays are celebrated in a super special way: they dim the lights and all tables take part in the celebration!  

Menu is consistent, with a lot of different avors and options. I had the pasta called Tinta (fettucine and calamari). It was nicely prepared, and delicious. The wine menu is not that extensive but decent.
author: Bruna P.

description:
La Traviata is a time warp back to the 1970's and I mean that in the best way possible. The walls are filled with signed celebrity pics and cheesy Glamour Shots from days gone by. The décor is homey and cozy and there are a few booth style tables in the front, great for a date or a small party. The menu is simple but provides every Italian staple you can imagine from Parma Ham w/ Melon to Carbonara and Lasagna. When you step inside you could swear you were in a traditional ristorante on the East Coast. Decent wine selections. The restaurant is opera themed so you will hear some borderline cheesy operatic classics like Figaro, but the music is not intrusive. If you are into this sort of nostalgia and want some local Italian food, then you'll enjoy this place. If you are looking for a hip, modern era joint, this is not the restaurant for you.

Food: 3 to 3.5 stars.
We ordered the Scaloppini al Funghi (veal, mushrooms w/ white wine sauce) and the Melanzane alla Vaness (layered eggplant parm). Both dishes were good and enjoyable and well portioned. However, the eggplant was a touch overcooked for our taste and the steamed vegetables were run of the mill and on the bland side. To be fair, it's exactly what you would expect from a time warp. The menu likely hasn't changed since they opened in 1973 and I kind of don't mind, anything else wouldn't make sense. Highlights are the bread, like everyone has mentioned and mushroom sauce. I would come back regardless, because I get the feeling all their dishes are good and they would rarely serve a bad meal.

Service/Atmosphere: 4 stars.
Servers were warm and respectfully attentive. They didn't try to sell us on anything or constantly check in, but they were there when you needed them and kept a watchful eye on the tables. Their strolling around the restaurant made for a nice background ambiance. Yes, they were a little aloof, but that's what you get at old school places and I like that level of service. 

Note: If someone in your party has a birthday, make sure to tell the staff. They have a cute little routine with the lights and music that is adorably hokey but fun. And there's cake with candles.

Price: 2.5 stars.
Kind of hating on the price, it's true, and it's probably a bit harsh. Problem is I can get some really fancy modern food around the corner for the same cost. Prices average around $9 appetizers,  $10 salads and $18 entrees. Two entrees and two glasses of wine will run you about a $50-$55 bill before tip.

Overall, I would go back if I was in the area and wanted a nice Italian meal.
author: Sam S.

description:
One of my favorite Italian restaurants in SF. The food is very authentic, full of flavor, and a great portion. The customer service is great. It was my wife's birthday, and they did an amazing birthday celebration for her. 

This is a great place for a date, or for the family. The food is very well priced especially for the quality. 

Will be back.
author: Mark L.

description:
I live in the east bay and had a doctor apt. in the mission, but boy, its not pretty any more, its filthy. 

So after apt. we walked around 45 min looking for a nice place....lotsa luck....
the and OMG! ....a miracle, we found La Traviata!! 

We ordered the parchment baked salmon, garden salads and a bottle of Byron Chardonnay recommended by the wait staff.  We finally relaxed in a comfort,  with w arm bread and butter, superb service, very reasonable prices with softly lilting opera music and fresh roses on the table.

Also you are surrounded by large scale drawings and photos of opera notables who dined there, even Placido Domingo whose charming photos with his young children are endearing.

This is an institution which should be supported.  Check Please Bay Area needs to know!!
 
Furthermore, I am a small person and I needed a boost to the table.  The waiter promptly brought me a comfy cushion so i was able to dine in total comfort.
author: Marsha R.

description:
If I could give this place 10 stars, I would. This place serves the best italian food I've ever had in the US. It is a cosy and lovely place in the Mission area, very close to the 24th street Bart. They start you off with this amazing warm bread that they bake on site. Then I had the eggplant appetizer, which was divine, and then the ravioli with their pink sauce. I was in heaven. I also tried their tiramisu and I've been in love every since

The serves was great, the ambiance was excellent... and the food is to die for. I'll be back often now that I've found my go-to italian place.
author: P D.

description: Incredible and authentic italian food! Got the gnocchi with creamy pesto and it was absolutely delicious. The entire place is homey and is an Italian gem found in the Mission. They bring out freshly baked bread to the table and have a very friendly atmosphere.
author: Emily G.

description: Casual, old skool Italian food. Casual is not quite right, it's very classy, small, intimate. Comfortable is a better word. My food was excellent. Service was good. The menu is pretty large and I look forward to returning.
author: Will D.

description:
Italian food in the mission?!  What is this?  I work not even a block away and I have no idea how I missed this little Gem!

The interior of this place is very cozy, intimate and comfortable.  The staff is humorous and old school feel good.  We had 9 in our party and they accommodated us without hesitation or reservation.

I had the Verdi which was delicious and I exhaled it.  I also snuck some forkfuls of the tiramisu which was delicious. 

Price points are very affordable at about $15/p after tax and tip for just an entree.   This place is great and I will definitely be back despite my general aversion to italian food.
author: Kat D.

description: The space was good and the service and staff were wonderful. Food was average. The price point is no different from most of the Italian restaurants in the city.
author: Sruja A.

description:
It's refreshing to have an authentic Italian spot in the heart of the mission. 

My boyfriend and I split the caesar salad and veal parm. The salad had classic dressing with just the right amount of garlic and anchovy. And the parm was super tender. It was a little pricey for just the meat served with no pasta. But the homemade bread helped fill us up. 

Overall, if you're looking for a homey, authentic italian spot, this is it. We will definitely be back.
author: Susie R.

description: Everything is delicious here, very quiet and romantic feel. Perfect for two love birds. It's so hidden, I love it. The server knows exactly what she's talking bout, very nice too, the only bad thing was no high chairs for babies. Please work on that. Thank you
author: Tania H.

description:
I love, love, love it!!! 
Cozy, hidden, family run Italian restaurant in the mission. 
They start you with this great fresh baked bread which is reason enough to go. 
Pasta was really good but not nearly as perfect as the alla Beverly sills. 
Good service, fresh Parmesan, no wait for water refills. 
Will definitely be back!
author: Caroline K.

description: I have been coming to this place for three years. Every time we are greeted with a warm Italian welcome. Love the hot bread. Usually get the Italian Barbera red wine. Salmon tonight was amazing.
author: Mark O.

description:
Best Italian.
100% real and authentic.
-Pasta is the best along with Homemade bread!
-REAL Tiramisu .NOTING ELSE LIKE IT , MUST TRY  
-Not a lot of parking
author: Stephanie B.

description: I love this place! It's simple, straightforward, family style Italian. We've tried several of the pastas and they've all been great. They also have a nice selection of reasonably priced wines by the glass. It's family run and the staff is super friendly. It's definitely a gem in a neighborhood that's filling up with overpriced and mediocre restaurants that cater to hipsters.
author: Diana G.

description:
Stumbled upon it near my house. Its fantastic...Authentic Italian, feels like you are in Europe or Manhatten...great atmosphere not noisy, casual or dressy both works, not a "scene" ...that Lasagna is insane and so was the Pancetta creamy pasta...can't wait for more! 

As someone who lives next door to Beretta this place is soooo much better and nicer attitudes... not a noisy over priced "scene" with wee plates you wait in long lines for.

Only missing cocktails:(
author: Sion S.

description:
This is possibly the most authentic Italian place I've ever been to. Upon walking in you'll notice the place is quaint. The walls are full of pictures and paintings. My favorite was the stain glass of a woman whose dress reminded me of Belle from Beauty and the Beast. But, back to the point.

La Traviata has a very family-oriented ambiance. Orders aren't typically taken until everyone in the party is present, but it's possible to order if someone is late. Freshly baked bread is served as you wait for everyone.

The complimentary bread has a crunchy crust and soft core. It was so fresh butter melts right when you put it on the bread (I'd recommend putting pieces of butter between the slices and once it's cool it's perfect).

I ordered the calamari al pomodoro. This isn't served with pasta, it's basically calamari cooked in a homemade red sauce complemented with a side of vegetables. It's really good if you're looking to eat something light.

All in all, the service was good, and I'd definitely come back.
author: Grace N.

description:
One of my favorite Italian restaurants in the City.

So authentic, so stereotypically Italian, so good! This is the perfect place to enjoy a real Italian meal in a quiet environment unlike most Mission restaurants.

I've been here three times and have ordered the same thing each time: Delicious salmon (en papillote) with olives, herbs and wine sauce. So good yet light and healthy, which can be hard to come by at many Italian restaurants.

Service is warm and friendly and the head chef is clearly proud and passionate about the quality of his food. The decor is warm and sets you back 20 years as soon as you walk in. To top it off, the prices are more than fair for such high quality.

Highly recommended if you're in the Mission, just don't mind the shady neighborhood.
author: Teiki K.

description: Hidden Italian gem in the heart of mission, service is really good, food from the appetizer to the dessert. Is a thumbs up!!! My entree was really good..i just got back from my vacation from Italy this one gives me the feel of the food and the coziness of an the small italian restaurant i loved..
author: Marnie P.

description: Love the food. Got pasta , hubby got veal. He is not a big fan of pasta, but this place makes him ate all my pasta. Veals with sautéed mushroom with white wine was great too. Cozy restaurant, love when the owner cares about their customers. Will definitely go back next time we visit San Francisco.
author: Nudi S.

description: Good, standard Italian food. Everything is tasty and the service is friendly, but most of the pastas on the menu could be made at home for much cheaper. The hot bread is a nice touch though.
author: Amy Y.

description: Love family spots but the food was just....eh not really good. Like I'd rather open a jar of Ragu season it up and eat it vs what we just had. The pasta with Italian sausage and mushroom was so watery it was like they were diluting the sauce. The sausage was good but the rest of the dish was bland & watery. Next was chicken stuffed with pancetta...ugh. Pancetta wasn't cooked through and it seems like they had forgotten to season the chicken. Broccoli and mushrooms served with the dish were frozen not fresh. And I won't even get into the walnut Gorgonzola salad. The bread was ok.
author: Gigi G.

description:
You know it's the real deal when the staff is speaking Italian! 

The missing star is for our initial reception: "How can I help you?" "Table for four, please." "Do you have a reservation?" "No." "It's a Friday night and you have no reservation?" "We were just in the area." "OK, let me check." From then, the service was excellent, even from that person. I don't know. Maybe it was a bad joke? 

Anyway, we ordered the Gamberi (prawn pasta), Ai Fungi (mushroom pasta), Al Tosca (chicken), and Cioppino (seafood). Everyone was very happy with their entrees. The garlic in all dishes was perfect, the calamari was the most tender I've had from anywhere, and the bread smelled so good as to be irresistible. I actually ordered the cioppino in part to allow myself to indulge in the bread, since the dish is straight up protein and no starch. 

Finally, the chicken and seafood entrees were substantial enough for doggy bags, and there was no fuss about getting four separate checks.
author: Amy N.

description: I used to work at an Italian restaurant years ago and I compare each place to my experiences. This was a very good, friendly staff, knowledgeable and steered us to the dishes that they thought would best suit our palette. It's funny to find this place deep in the Mission district but the food was good and the prices were reasonable. I am coming back here.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
La Parodia

Culinary outposts in ethnic neighborhoods incongruent with their featured ethnic fare, still fueled by the passion of their founders, can be more than mere relief from the monotony of their competitors. Judging from the accolades among obsolete, unrecommended hidden reviews here, this former success is what funded the elaborate ceiling in this business, and explained the contrastingly plain and paltry plates it served last night.

The visual differences between my cioppino (seafood stew) and the one depicted here are: mine had less fish (2 cubes), more prominently placed pawns (2), less calamari (2 rings), and no parsley.

The overcooked bay scallops and prawns in under-salted, garlic-less, thin orange broth, priced at the menu's apex, would probably not have survived the original chef's taste test, owner's scrutiny, or server's pride. Sixty dollars for this, no wine, appetizer or dessert, and my Buddhist biker buddy's custom garlic fettuccini slop is undeserved charity that merely forestalls its un-tragic, imminent, Mission hipster gentrification.
author: Eclectic E.

description:
Amazing Italian food really!
I took the fungi pasta which were great but actually my friend had lasagna and they are just the best I ever tried - I'm French and I've been in Italy a few times
Service is very professional and friendly
I definitely recommend the place
author: Sophie G.

description:
I am charmed. This place has my heart, I will surely be back again and again. These places can so easily slip through the cracks in a city that has more restaurants per capita than any other, and it is only growing. It is a sanctuary, it is living, backed by a story that I hope you come to know and understand from your experience there. I hope to see this place continue to thrive.

 A pasta craving led us to the nearest Italian eatery on Mission St. An un-assuming entryway gave way to one of the more charming dining experiences that I have had in this city for at least a few months. The interior walls are covered in a lovely collection of both family photos and those of great opera stars. The intricate ceiling is backed by a story just as interesting as the fixture itself. We came with a group of four and sipped on two bottles of the Vernaccia, why order something else when we enjoyed that bottle so much? The wine prices are super reasonable to boot. Hot, crunchy bread came to our table, and I felt that with the butter knives and pre-portioned butter, there was a particular focus on traditional dining etiquette supported here that made the experience only that much more memorable. The two servers that were managing the floor missed no detail, and were sweet as well as witty.

We ordered the Ceasar salad, which if you are looking for the classic super creamy stuff, I will advise that this salad does not meet that description. The dressing, while it still had delightful anchovy flavor, was more of a vinaigrette, which I was later grateful to have saved the extra calories for our pastas. We also shared the prosciutto and melon, a classic, I love it and you can expect no frills with this one. And finished our appetizers with the fried mozzarella with marinara, think mozzarella stick big enough for the table.. Great to share! Eat it fast tho, so the cheese stays nice and melty. 

We each ordered a pasta for the main course. Two house made gnocchi, very soft and creamy in texture. One came with a pesto sauce, which sadly I didn't taste, and my choice came with the aurora (pink sauce.) The other two dishes were a hearty slice of house-made lasagna bolognese, again a very classic interpretation with not-too-big of a slab. The unanimous winning dish at our table was the pasta carbonara, in all it's creamy, pancetta glory. 

My only critique about the savories, is that I felt that they were lacking in salt, but luckily that is something we easily fixed, of course. And still not worth "losing a star" for. 

We closed the restaurant down, joined at the end only by John, the restaurants owner. They surprised us with a lovely tiramisu to end our meal which had delicious hints of orange liqueur. We sipped on a little swirl of Vin Santo, to round out the perfect meal.
author: Brandi B.

description: I wish I could give more than a 5 rating.  This place never disappoints.  The service and staff are fabulous, and truly make you feel welcome.  To start, the bread is always fresh, warm and flaky.  One can truly fill up with only the bread, but I have to force myself to stop to leave room for the meal and dessert.  My favorite is the dover sole.  To die for.  Finished off with the divine tiramisu, it always makes for a fabulous experience.  Living in the Sacramento area, we don't have the opportunity to enjoy La Traviata as often as we would like.
author: John L.

description: Good food, good service, very accommodating. Simple italian cuisine - the lasagna was a favorite as well as the carbonara.
author: Camille E.

description: The food and the service were delightfully old-school Italian. We started with the bruschetta, a caesar salad, and tortellini en brodo. For entrees, we had eggplant parmesan, frutti di mare, and pasta gamberi. Our dolci were tiramisu and spumone. Everything was delicious! The owners/waitstaff work together seamlessly. My only complaint is that they don't limit how much yummy warm bread and butter they give you.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Italian is few and far between in this neighborhood. As such, I settled for this place, but will not be going back any time soon. I was in the mood for some basic Italian staples. A Caesar Salad and some bolognese - I ordered both. And for good measure, also tried the vinaigrette marinated octopus. The octopus looked and tastes like it had come out of a processed can and was tossed in a bowl of Newman's. The Caesar was served room temp and was only saved by the waiters generous offer of cheese.  And without a bolognese option, I settled for sausage and mushroom with fresh tomatoes. Sausage and mushrooms - yes, fresh tomatoes - no. A few Roma tomatoes cut in half with some canned sauce doesn't quite count as Italian.  

Nice staff and service though. Has the feel of an old family place. Should have known better when I ordered the food by the pics of carbonarra on yelp - yikes!
author: Bill S.

description:
Came here with a friend for his birthday last night.  Yum yum!
Authentic, classic but low-frill Italian food experience.  We had something from almost every course:  melon with prosciutto; greens with blue cheese and walnuts; linguine carbonara; veal parmagiana; tiramisu and decaf.  The least expensive italian wines (sangiovese and pinot grigio) did the job beautifully.  We had a great time and would definitely come back.
author: Danielle R.

description:
Mama Mia this place never fails to deliver!

The servers are not always that attentive / distracted, but you can tell their heart is in it and they're all warm people.  

Pretty much everything I have here is great, and the prices are really reasonable.
author: Charlie B.

description:
For many years, an icon of Italian food in an incongruous place. I have never had a so-so dish of anything here, and portions are large.

Take the BART here: finding parking is not easy.
author: George T.

description: 4 of us here and everyone had delicious food! Especially loved the tortellini! Waiter was friendly and helpful and loved the atmosphere. Would definitely come back!
author: Lonnie C.

description: This is s lovely spot. I love the ambiance-family portraits amongst photos of Italian opera divas -/ my kind of place. The gnocchi in Aurora sauce were perfect. Aurora is the pink vodka sauce, yet this was ultra-creamy. I ordered it as a side, which a good idea. As tasty & fluffy as the gnocchi were, the sauce is EXTREMELY rich. I also ordered a tasty glass of Montepulciano, & before I ordered it, the excellent server Lala brought 2 other tastes for me to try. What a great waitress! I ordered the chicken picattta. The white wine-caper sauce was excellent but the chicken had a rubbery consistency I didn't care for, but the savory lemon-caper sauce was so good I didn't care. If you are looking for authentic Italian outside North Besch try La Traviata. Apparently it's been here in the Mission for years. Which I love of course. It's not quite as good as Poesia in the Castro, but then again it's half the price.i also love it because it looks & feels like Italiani restaurants my parents took me to when I was a kid. Suggestion to the manager: choose a higher quality of poultry & add a starch-- like rice pilaf would be great with picattta. This would 5 stars  were it not for the rubbery processed chicken. But the sauce! So good.
author: Connie C.

description: Best Italian meal I have ever had. I went here for my birthday and it was amazing. The bread was so hot and fresh, and the service was great and fast. I had the gnocchi in the cream sauce and my boyfriend had the cheese tortellini in the cream sauce and we loved it so much we decided we are coming here every year to celebrate our birthdays!
author: Daniella C.

description:
Unique atmosphere. Good food.

Definitely worth going at least once for the experience. Service was very friendly.
author: Lani N.

description: Nice, cute Italian restaurant. We have eaten caprese, tortellini and al tosca.. Caprese was ordinary. But tortellini and al tosca were very very delicious. Service was great. I m sure that we will come here again!
author: Onur T.

description:
My girlfriends and I made a reservation for 4 and when we arrived we were seated immediately. I really loved the ambiance of this little restaurant. The walls are filled with old timey pictures, the tables all had flowers on them, the lights were dimmed. We noticed a lot of people on dates and a couple larger groups celebrating birthdays. Our server came over and took our order and then quickly returned with a basket of bread. This was some damn good bread. It was warm and fresh from the oven. So good! Another girl and I both ordered the peso gnocchi, and when it came out, we quickly realized we should have just ordered one because the portions were HUGE. Each of us were only able to eat half and I felt really guilty for not being able to get it to go  (we were on vacation and our hotel didn't have a fridge.)

My only qualm with my experience here is that my friend and I both ordered a glass of the house wine and it was really bad. It tasted like an old shoe. We should have said something, but we didn't so that's on us, but I recommend getting one of the more expensive wines.

I would definitely return. Everything on the menu sounded delicious and I would love to come back next time I find myself in San Francisco.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
A very nice restaurant, great for romance and outstanding Italian cuisine, always magical for us.

The food has never disappointed us and has always been my wife's favorites for anniversaries, birthdays, etc.  I arranged for a dozen red roses to be delivered to the restsurant on our first visit and the staff volunteered to make those arrangements for us and always managed to blend the roses into the magic of dining there.  They always made it a very special night for us.

The surprise was the owners and staff who made us feel welcome as though we were distant cousins visiting their home.  Very genuine, warm, and friendly people.

The food was just an integral part of the evening's magic, as it is exquisite and exceptional.  It's every bit as good as the old country.  (For those who may not know what I mean by that, it's authentic Italian, the kind my grandmother made.)  Absolutely delicious from the first hot bread served to the last bite of the entree.  (Of course, the staff always spoiled my wife with something special for our anniversary and our birthdays.)

We always hate leaving the restaurant.  How much more elegant a recommendation can I make?
author: Thomas H.

description:
Oh La Traviata! How do I love thee let me count the ways...

Let's start with the fresh bread! It comes to your table piping hot.. it's so hard not to eat this stuff before your food comes, I like to put butter in the slices and let it melt. Drool! It's an amazing complement to all those leftover sauces that need to be soaked up and eaten! I mean,  who serves fresh bread anymore?! 

Moving on to the Eggplant Parmigiana. It's cheesy and delicious, the marinara is sweet and acidic and pairs well with the cheese and the eggplant -it melts in your mouth. I can't take a bite without doing the happy dance.

The Lasagna is hearty and delicious,  I don't crave Lasagna often but when I do this is the place to eat it, and it's HUGE. I know a lot of regulars that come here just for this.

All the seafood here is delicious and always fresh! (I'm a seafood snob) The Seafood Pasta and the Salmon in Parchment Paper are amongst my favorites.  (other patrons will look at your table in envy as the Salmon is lifted out of the steaming parchment paper table-side) 

They have a great wine list.  Circue di Vin is my go to bottle.

And I must not forget the friendly staff! They really do make you feel like family here! 

This is also great place to dine if you have a group! 

I love this place and can't wait to come back!
(And now i'm craving eggplant parm)
author: Kadi H.

description: This establishment was amazing! Created a Yelp account to share my experience. Owner Gjeff was friendly and helpful with suggestions and guidance. Everything was delicious. The fresh baked bread was crazy good. Probably ate too much of it as it kept coming-and he allowed me to have a fresh loaf (2) to take with my leftovers. We started with the fig salad and a bottle of white. Perfect balance. Shared the Funghi pasta and the Alla Beverly Sills. Both were absolutely fabulous. Pasta was al dente and so flavorful. Chicken was moist and juicy - wonderfully complimented by the stuffings. Finished up with the tiramisu. We couldn't finish it all but still wanted more. I live in New York and know Italian food. Their dishes rival any Italian restaurant I have dined in. I will be back to La Traviata every time I visit San Francisco. Do yourself a flavor favor and dine here.
author: KerryAnne W.

description: This place is amazing, I loved it! It's great for date night and family dinners too.Can't wait to go back.
author: LoLi H.

description:
Yes, we managed to find the ONE italian restaurant in the mission!!

A really cute spot that is what you think of when they say "family restaurant". Lots of interesting photos framed on the walls, and friendly staff that may or may not be all of the same family..

Wine + pasta + enough seating for a larger party (we had ~8)!
author: Suejung S.

description:
A Italian restaurant with real Italians? In San Francisco? Weird, I know.

We stumbled upon La Traviata after deciding an hour wait for a restaurant down the street was... not coo. The future mother-in-law was itching for some Italian, so what better than a restaurant named after an Italian opera!

Though we were first hesitant upon dining at a then-empty restaurant, our trust in Yelp Reviews persuaded us to give it a shot.

We were not disappointed. Eggplant and Veal Parmigiana and a Chicken Picatta were ordered... along with a bottle of Italian wine.

Wine was good.
The Parmigiana were good as well.
I, the orderer of the Chicken Picatta. It was... meh.

BUT, service was excellent, 3 out of 4 dishes were consumed with gusto (the 4th was completely finished too).

Definitely a nice, legitimately Italian-Italian restaurant.

Would definitely come back.

There were plenty of people dining when we were leaving the restaurant, many that looked like regulars... so once a gun, Yelp saved the day!
author: Victor C.

description: The service here is incredible and the food is even better.  The delicious hot bread is unique and tasty, and friendly attentive staff remind me of my favorite family Italian establishments back home.  The atmosphere is authentic with the photos of opera stars with the owner and the opera music in the background.  Fun!  I seriously can't wait to come back here.  The tiramisu was exceptional with just a hint of orange citrus.  Try the puttanesca, calamari, or the tortellini!  Pricing was reasonable.  Excellent selection of Italian wines.
author: Zach T.

description:
This review is not rating the food - never had the opportunity to taste any here - the one star is for the manager/server with a bad attitude who thinks he can treat customers like late schoolboys (or tardy prentices).

Had a reservation for 7:00pm. 

Got delayed in traffic/parking and got to the restaurant at 7:20pm. 

We walked in. 

Manager/server came up. 

We mentioned that we had a reservation. 

The first words from the manger are "what time is it?" 

Not "what is your name?" Not "what time is your reservation for?" Not "welcome to the restaurant!" 

He then proceeded to berate us for being late and described how he has too many customers for him to (want to) hold a reservation. 

Two Seinfeld episodes crossed my mind - the Soup Nazi kicking George out for asking for bread - and Seinfeld sharing his thoughts about taking/holding a reservation: "See, you know how to take the reservation, you just don't know how to *hold* the reservation and that's really the most important part of the reservation, the holding. Anybody can just take them."

We walked out.

We went to a restaurant that actually wanted our business.
author: Pubudu W.

description:
Their free bread is so warm and crunch! (i know so cheap of me to mention)

I tried their tortellini and it was really delicious. The cheese wasn't too heavy and the portion was decent sized
author: Dorris W.

description:
Best Italian restaurant in SF!
The salmon was amazing!
The tiramisu desert was scrumptious!
A must try if your looking for truly awesome Italian food!
author: Alexandra H.

description:
Why trek all the way to North Beach when this is 3 blocks away? La Traviata is good, simple Italian food. Great gnocchi pomodoro. My friend got the house tortellini in a cream sauce, which is miraculously not a heavy as it sounds. Delicious. 

They serve bread fresh and steaming  from the oven. I ate an embarrassing amount of it. 

Service was wonderful. 

Prices are incredibly reasonable; we paid $60 for 2 entrees, 2 glasses of wine, and an appetizer. 

Go. This is a neighborhood gem that I almost hesitate to review for feat that it will get crowded.
author: Jillian P.

description:
If there ever was a place that lived up to the phrase "hidden gem" this is it. Nestled in between low-end shops and burrito stops is this adorable and quite wonderful restaurant.

As a NYer I admit to being an Italian food snob - we have some of the best Italian food in the world in NYC. La Traviata rivals the best. 

Upon entering a beautiful if old fashioned parlor type room we were heartily greeted and shown to a table. We were promptly served water and hot bread and butter. Our waiter was warm and welcoming but not intrusive. Our table had real linens, a real flame oil candle and 2 real red roses - very classy. The walls are crammed with photos of opera greats, many either taken in the restaurant, or head shots autographed praising the restaurant.

I had eggplant Parmesan and my husband had a seafood & linguine dish in a cream sauce. My eggplant was perfect - not slimy or oily, the skin wasn't tough, the breading did not separate from the eggplant - and the red sauce was very good, not sweet or acidic but perfectly balanced. My husband's dish had ample seafood - clams, mussels, calamari, scallops, etc - and the sauce was very good, not too liquidy as sometimes happens with seafood but not thick or gloppy either. 

For dessert my husband had the tiramisu, a generous and lovely serving which he rated very tasty. My dessert was great - not exactly what I'd pictured based on the description but tasty, generous and rich none the less - profiteroles in chocolate mousse (the menu simply said "chocolate" so the mousse was a surprise) with ample dollops of whipped cream.

The prices were very reasonable, the water refills prompt and the service outstanding, all on top of just really good tasting food.
author: Emily G.

description:
I live in Russian Hill, and although North Beach is a skip away, this genuinely Italian restaurant in the Mission has charm enough for me to make the trip.  

First, the staff at Traviata is absolutely loveable.  They are friendly and engaging, just as if you were welcome guests in their home.    Special mention to Jack, John and Naudia who always make every visit to La Traviata a positively magical experience.

Anyway, let me just say, one of the best things about running half marathons is the pre-race CARB LOAD.  The pasta here is generous, filling, and delicious.  My typical meal goes like this:  

Appetizer:  Bruschetta, with mushrooms and goat cheese (i think this is off-menu)
Salad:  Caesar. The dressing is simple, made with fresh ingredients, and full of flavor.. it's definitely not the mayonnaisey gobs of caesar from the bottle.
Main Course: I've ordered the pasta ai Funghi and alla carrera most often because I love the simplicity and the heartiness of homestyle spaghetti.  Everyone I've come here with has never ordered a dish they didn't enjoy, so worry not about your menu decision :)

In response to a recent one-star review, I would never show up late to a reservation without calling in a notice, especially on a busy night, and especially with a large table.  Shame on you.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
I ate an entire basket of bread, while my carb-avoidant boyfriend just stared at me with a mixture of shock and pity on his face. I've been trying to hide my glutton for gluten from him for so long, but this bread broke my will. It's probably the most delicious restaurant bread I've ever experienced. 

The entrees are good, too. I got the Chicken Alla Beverly Sills, and he had the Scallopini Al Funghi. Both dishes were very good, but I wasn't wild about the mushroom/onion sauce that came on both. I'll probably ask for the sauce on the side next time. My boyfriend loved both dishes, though, and was raving. 

The restaurant doesn't look like much on the outside, but the decor is lovely. The whole restaurant is just one small room, with a smaller waiting room in front. 

It's cozy, warm, and makes for a nice, romantic dinner where you can get a good meal for $60 or so.
author: Taylor B.

description:
First time to La Traviata in the Mission and it was really good! I'm not sure if it's the best lasagna I've ever had, but I can't remember any better. Rich cheese and a crusty baked cheese top.  Great eggplant appetizer and the homemade baked bread is awesome. Linguine vongole also good and I liked my chianti. The only sub-par item was the Caesar. Reasonable prices, good old school Italian vibe, not hard to get in.

I'll be happy to return, and happy to bring people here.
author: G M.

description:
Conversation: 

"If I have another goddamn taco in my mouth I will kill things" - Me

"I feel like Italian" - Man

"I would skin nineteen babies for some bruschetta right now" - Me

"Is there Italian other than Delfina and Farina in the Mish?" - Man

"Fuck those places. I don't make 400k a year. Let's call The Queer" - Me

And The Queer, who's lived here for 30 years and knows everything about San Francisco, steered us in the direction of La Traviata. 

PS: Try the bruschetta. It's better than mine, and I make damn good bruschetta.
author: Mel H.

description:
This particular spot can be candle lit and quaint. Whenever you go with they ask should you be accomplishing sign up for as well as dinner with, should you be dinner with, they seat you to definitely still left (which I'm sure will be the just seating spot from what exactly We remember). Wide open home and signup for the suitable.

Many of us received the channel 12" Pizzas Pesto (came having basil pesto having sunshine dried out tomatoes, reddish onions and african american olives) having further sausages. The chicken wings had been dished up broiling warm and had been lower in to 6 slices... the perfect number of chicken wings if not a great deal to talk about between a couple of folks that aren't way too eager. The number of african american olives had been surprisingly mind-boggling. x___x;;; 

I know LOATHE african american olives, nevertheless my pal wants them, consequently many of us maintained them within our order and I recently picked them out and about on their own. The pesto spices had been really simple (there had been basically scarcely any sauce) and We truthfully did not flavor too much of the chicken wings aside from the olives.: d 

It had been as long as We tad into a area of my personal peel of chicken wings in which We experienced the opposite toppings which i experienced some other immediate burst open of taste. The chicken wings isn't really anything amazing, nevertheless it can be certainly not undesirable.
author: James T.

description:
I've lived in SF for ten years, eat out all the time (the whole range from tacos to fine dining) and unfortunately I can't remember a meal this bad.
Two stars because the service was good- kind, attentive, helpful. So that makes me unable to give just one star. But unfortunately the food was not good. And not in an "off night bad" way, but in a "the recipes, ingredients, and cooking methods need to change" way.
I love the idea of a family owned Italian spot on mission by 24th serving good traditional fare, but the food left everything to be desired.
I hope they improve!
author: Nicholas R.

description:
La Traviata is a family style little restaurant in the Mission District.  Parking can be tough in that area, so it is better to give extra time for parking.

Service 5/5:  We made the reservation at 8pm but we were running late.  Since it was Valentine's day, they only could hold the table for another 10 minutes.  We rushed and finally got there 8:12pm.  The guy told us that we needed to wait another 10 minutes but he was so nice and friendly to offer us drinks (no charge).  Finally we got seated at 8:30pm.  Everyone was so friendly and warm there.  Definitely a plus!

Decor 5/5:  Very cozy, warm and down to earth.  It made you feel like home.  I especially like the photos on the wall.  Nice homely feel.

Food 4/5:  

For starter, we had the Portabello stuffed with cheese.  It was so GOOD.  The portabello cooked very well and perfect to go with the cheese.  Perfect amount and not too much.  Flavorful but not salty.

For entree:  My friend got the chicken and I got the salmon.  Both dishes came with a side of pasta.  You could choose from tomato sauce or cream sauce.  Both sauces were very good.  Personally I like the chicken more than the salmon.  The chicken was tender, juicy and moist.  The salmon was ok but kinda oily to me.

Forgot to mention the free bread.  It was so good.  Warm and fresh.  Perfect to start but be careful don't eat too much before your main dishes come out!
author: Liza T.

description:
The fried Mozzarella was awful and so was the eggplant Parmesan.  Service wasn't great and the servers were condensending. 
But the bread was amazing and the tortellini was great. Not the best ambiance.
author: Cheri R.

description:
Incredible!  This is the best italian restaurant I've been to in the states!  Not only is the food incredibly delicious, but the prices are very reasonable (pastas under 20, appetizers under 10).  

I had the carbonara - it's one of my favorite dishes and it's hard to find a place that gets it right.  Let me tell you, they got it right - excellent parmesan flavor with tender pancetta!

We'll be visiting the Mission a lot more now, thanks to this new discovery!
author: Chris S.

description: Looked for a cozy/ intimate LOCAL setting to share with my wife on our anniversary and totally scored. Starting with atmosphere and laid back not in your face service, we had the cozy part covered. Fig balsamic salad- amazing. the gnocchi was authentic and hand-made. Breaded mozzarella-good lawd!!! Generous portions, fast to the table...even the coffee was full bodied served with real heavy cream. Watch out, you'll want to take the chef home! Grazi!!
author: Steph R.

description:
The man was craving some hearty Italian food, but I was in the snuggle-up-at-home-and-snack mood. So we compromised and ordered food to-go from La Traviata.

The place is really warm and cozy. Framed portraits line the wall with comfy-looking booth tables. It would've been nice to hang out if I was in the mood.

(I know, I'm such a bummer sometimes.)

We ordered the fried mozzarella, and it was smuuuthurrrrred in marinara sauce. This was deliciously dangerous and I could see myself eating three of these, and then crying into my pint of ice cream about all the fat I just ate. Totally worth the tears.

As an entree, I opted for the salmone, thinking it was a lighter option (than the carb-ladden pasta), but I'm pretty sure I was wrong. I asked for it broiled, but it was pretty oily and not at all light fare. It was accompanied by linguine with red sauce; which was just... OK.

The man opted for the spaghetti with sausage. It was heavenly, but there was a TON of it. You decide if that's good or bad.

I really liked that the meal came with free bread and even a slice of tiramisu (which was really tasty).

Would I go back? Probably not.
But even though the place is really warm and cozy? Yeah, no.

I told you I'm a bummer sometimes.
author: Adena B.

description: We came here last minute for my birthday dinner. There were five of us and all of us felt like the food was delicious. I had the tortellini and it was some of the best tortellini I had ever had. The atmosphere had a very family feeling to it; They lowered the lights and sang happy birthday to me at the end of the dinner. The service was fantastic as well. I am so happy we chose this place for dinner; I honestly don't think we could have picked a better place!
author: Brenna W.

description:
My friend and I ate here last night and there was a MOUSE IN THE DINING ROOM. We saw it scurrying around a diner's feet and alerted that table, and then the mouse ran towards the kitchen. Thoroughly disgusting.

Even worse, when we told the waitress, she just shrugged it off and said there was nothing she could do about it. When we told the manager, he agreed to comp my meal, which I had absolutely no appetite for, but charged us for my friend's meal, our drinks, and mentioned that they have an exterminator come in every month. Nothing was done to address the mouse that had just run into their kitchen, apparently.

The food is average -- what little I had of it before I saw the mouse.
author: Robin L.

description: Came in here with a reservation for a party of 4. The service was wonderful from beginning to end and the food was delicious!
author: Mai L.

description: We had a lovely and delicious dinner for my partner's birthday. I highly recommend this place not only for it's ambience but for it's authentic homemade cooking that reminded me of my grandmother's pasta sauce! The decor is warm and tasteful and reminds me of restaurants in New York's Little Italy!  They graciously served my partner a delectable Tiramisu accompanied by dim lighting and operetic birthday music!  I highly recommend this place for entertaining family and friends.
author: Arthur C.

description:
This place has been around and serving top notch AUTHENTIC dego food since before 'foodie' was even a word, and the neighborhood was full of 'workinmen'.

Well, now the Mission is foodie paradise, and there is no shortage of high caliber Italian around town.

But a plate of linguine and clams (vongole) served by Zef and family just can't go wrong.

Ahhh... the memories!
author: Josh K.

description:
I would recommend this restaurant to anyone.  It is a quiet place with great ambiance, good food, and good service.  I like to go there when I have close friends or family visiting (or when I'm on a date), because the noise level is almost always very low, so you can have a casual conversation without yelling at one another in order to hear.

John, the owner is incredibly friendly, as is Jack, the older man who has worked at the restaurant for many years, when he is not off traveling the world and visiting his son overseas.  Both provide excellent customer service, and a great all around experience.

FYI, if you like salmon AT ALL, then you absolutely should try their salmon dish.  It's prepared unlike any salmon you have ever eaten, and is their most popular dish on the menu!
author: Steve C.

description:
This place is actually the best. Amazing food, outstanding service...no complaints. Each person gets a full loaf of bread when they arrive...what's to complain about that?

This is great for a date night or a night of with friends. I'm overly satisfied and I WILL be back!
author: Caitlin H.

description:
New favorite date place in the mission. It feels very warm and cozy, yet classy, with 2 fresh (and perfect!) red roses on every table. For fellow Disney fans, there is a very Beauty-and-the-Beast-esque stained glass window at the entrance. 

Food was fantastic, except for the starter. The calamari did not impress (the, but the seafood pasta with white wine sauce was incredible. The sauce was very subtle yet tasty, really bringing out the fresh seafood without a hint of fishiness. Gnocchi with pesto was fresh and garlicky goodness.

Watch out for the bread - highly addictive.
author: Judy L.

description: The food was delicious!!!!! Definitely better than Olive Garden! Definitely coming back! The tomato sauce was so fresh & tasty! It really gives you an Italian feel unlike other major food chains.
author: Pthang C.

description:
3.5 stars. Came here with a large group of 8 and they were able to easily accomodate us with advance reservations.

Highlights:
- Complimentary warm bread. WARM being the key word. Nothing like warm crusty bread to melt the butter. mmm. 
- Pasta di Mare ($19.95) which is mixed seafood with linguine. Your choice of red or white cream or white wine sauce. I went with white cream. More calories but hey I was eating out and wanted to enjoy the creamy sauce.  Loaded with calamari, shrimp, scallops, and clams (I opted out of mussels). Very satisfying. There were a few shells or sandy things though.

DESSERT
- Panna cotta - my favorite, since this was clean, smooth, refreshing, and not too sweet. Delish.
- Tiramisu - was solid. No complaints.

Friendly service especially amazing since we were waited on by a 75 year old gentleman. 

Warm little restaurant.
author: Cindy W.

description: This place is everything I want in an Italian restaurant! It's got that home style charm... AMAZING FOOD! And nice waiters. Prices aren't to bad. I'll be back for sure
author: Ash M.

description: Tortellini alla Romana, bread rolls and flan were all great.  Our waiter was also an older italian gentleman, which helped w/ the authenticity.
author: Mike Q.

description:
Amazing bread with salted butter, the rarest thing to find in the US (I'm from France and I miss good bread with salted butter). 
The decor is very typical, warm, italian, with pictures hanging all over the walls. 
waitress was absolutely delightful and made her best for us to enjoy the meal.
Good caprese insalata with fresh tomatoes and decent mozzarella. 
The veal milanese with parmesan and mozarella was delicious, the sweetbread not as much, but I definitely want to try the home made gnocchis next time! 
The Panna Cotta was not with vanilla but with lime, it was good, not as good as mine though. 

Conslusion: it's not the best italian restaurant I've been to in my life, but I mean in Paris the food is so good that it's hard to compare (no bragging). Would recommend this place 100% because of 1. the bread, 2. the nice waiters, 3. very very decent food :)
author: Julie G.

description:
We stumbled onto this place by complete accident. La Traviata is perfect in every sense of the word. 

The ambiance: 
Cozy, yet you feel like the entire place was set up just for you. Has beautiful opera music in the background, but just loud enough for you to enjoy and not interrupt your conversation. Fresh roses at every table. You FEEL the effort they put in this restaurant and you don't want to leave.

The staff:
One of the best servers I've ever had the pleasure of meeting. An Italian server, who knew the food inside and out, knew their wine and made the night just a pleasure.

The food:
Phenomenal bread! 

Our Antipasto Misto went beautifully with our bottle of Nero d'Avola. The server recommended that particular Sicilian wine based on the dishes we ordered, as well as our personal preferences. We must have chatted with him for over 20 minutes, regarding the wine, and he really seemed like he was enjoying the conversation and took his time to go over every choice.

I ordered the Alla Carreras, which was a steal for $13. Perfectly cooked and seasoned pasta with pieces of Italian sausage, mushrooms, & fresh tomatoes. 

A friend ordered the Carbonara. She just loved the pancetta (Italian bacon) lightly tossed in eggs, cream and butter with her pasta. Only $12!



If you care about a classy girl, especially if she loves Opera, then this is a MUST date place. You will seriously thank me! 

Definitely an unforgettable night in San Francisco. Thank you, La Traviata.
author: Roman T.

description: I've never left a Yelp review before but this place is incredible. Went there on a date & not only are the staff so utterly delightful, but the food is incredible & really reasonable. I ordered the carbonara & asked for it to come with Italian sausage, which was so rich & flavoursome & delicious. My date had the lasagna which was equally gorgeous ; perfectly cooked; melt-in-the mouth delicious & the wine the waiter recommended went with it perfectly. Even the bread is amazing, & the profiteroles are so light with the most sinfully delicious chocolate, they're a must! The atmosphere of the place is lovely; it's low-key & not too formal that it's intimidating, but great Italian music and roses on the tables. Can't recommend more. (And seriously; leave room for that bread.)
author: Roe M.

description: Very authentic and very fresh pasta dishes, excellent / the staff is great, service is excellent - the ambience is very old school and wouldn't be bad if not for the location, which is terrible/the desserts are way too sweet: the presentation looks like the kind of desserts we made when we were kids ie: hersheys chocolate squirt bottle and tastes like it too -
author: E S.

description:
Cannot believe this place is rated 4 stars. We sat down and literally spent 26 minutes waiting for a simple bowl of minestrone. Another couple that came in 10 minutes after us got served their salads before us. It was rather insulting.

When our food finally arrived, we were getting ready to leave when the waiter became offended and had the nerve to raise his voice at my husband, saying "WE DO EVERYTHING FOR YOU, WE BRING YOU BREAD, WE BRING YOU BUTTER, WE BRING YOU OIL, WE BRING YOU THIS, WE BRING YOU THAT", all in a vehement obnoxious raised voice.

I mean, isn't that a waiter's job? to bring bread, oil and butter? Seriously, basically we just came in to waste half an hour and get yelled at, all while eating bland white bread.
author: Jade R.

description:
Kitschy yet romantic; takes reservations; good for a group; affordable. 

Order the salmon. Perfect size portions of tortellini. Tiramisu. Yum.
author: chloe w.

description:
I would bump this rating up to a 3-star. La Traviata is more of a great neighborhood restaurant than a destination place. Decent Italian-American food, old-school vibe and solid service. I wouldn't be surprised to hear Dino or "Old Blue Eyes" on the speakers and is that the reincarnated Rat Pack lounging in a dim corner? 

A basket of piping hot bread started the meal. Nothing fancy, just white bread rolls but it is a perfect way to warm your tummy on a cold winter's night. Everybody enjoyed their entrees. Shared dessert. Enjoyed the cream puffs more than the creme caramel. You won't find "gourmet" food here, just an honest meal at reasonable prices.

An unpretentious mom-and-pop atmosphere with real white tablecloths, kitschy photos of famous and once famous guests (mostly opera singers) and opera music playing in the background. A regular (but not Valentine's Day special) date night kind of place hidden in the gritty Mission, just steps from the BART station on 24th.
author: Cece E.

description:
Very cute Italian restaurant in the mission. It's opera-themed, with the walls completely covered in framed pictures. There is opera music playing in the background, and every table has a fresh rose in a vase. The wait staff was very friendly and overall it was a great experience.

The food was pretty good too --- tried the caprese salad, the lasagna, and the chicken pasta with cream sauce. The food was a bit on the heavy side, with ample portions. It turned out to be ideal for me because I was quite hungry!

I think this would be a great place to take a date. It's not too expensive, yet it's classy in its own way. My only complaint is a minor one... I wish they offered some sort of chocolate dessert! They had some standard Italian things; panna cotta, tira misu, etc. but nothing for the real chocolate-lovers.
author: Laurent L.

description:
I had dinner here once. I vaguely remember the entrees. They were good. 

But OMFG, the rolls. THOSE BEAUTIFUL, HOT, CRUSTY ROLLS THAT LET OUT SOME STEAM WHEN YOU BREAK THEM OPEN JUST LIKE IF THEY WERE IN A COMMERCIAL OR SOMETHING. YOU KNOW, THE KIND WHERE THE BUTTER JUST MELTS INSTANTLY ON CONTACT. 

And they kept on coming. After being seated: Oh, here's a basket of rolls for you. Appetizers arrive: Oh, here's another basket of rolls. Entrees arrive: Here, use these piping hot rolls to soak up the gravy. Check arrives: Oh, here's another basket of delicious rolls because we know you'll eat them up.

Rolls.
author: James Y.

description: Truly a little gem in the mission owned by a family. I ordered take out twice in one week because I absolutely loved how they were accommodating with my order. I asked them for a chicken fettaccini with broccoli and mushrooms with a pesto cream sauce. The chicken was very moist and the pasta overall had a balanced taste. They also give warm bread which I enjoyed dipping in my sauce. The homemade tiramisu is delish. A little pricey for the portion, but definitely worth it. Cant wait to dine in next time with my husband and try different dishes.
author: Ella A.

description:
Had yet another outstanding dinner here tonight.  They offered a special Valentine menu with new items and a few 'staples'.  The portobello appetizer was delicious, and I had the Lasagna.  Perfect.  Their mini bread loafs (with plenty of butter) are to die for.
Hands down - this is the best Italian restaurant I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing.
author: John L.

description:
+ Amazing food!
+ Cozy, great for catching up with friends / dates
+ Great mom and pop service
+ Sweet decor. The restaurant is covered almost wall-to-wall in photos, AND they have a stain glass window inside (common, stain glass window?!)

My new favorite Italian place!!!! Everything down the bread is amazing. Must order the Cacciatora (chicken dish) & pasta di mare. So effing delicious. I'm seldom impressed by pasta, but everything was so well put together- good balanced flavor and not just a flavor explosion.

Went there 2 weeks in a row probably resulting to a 5 lb weight gain..... and I'D DO IT AGAIN 10X OVER! Keep the good stuff coming, La Traviata!
author: Margaret T.

description: Came for a second time and was blown away. The Salmone alla Maxwell was the best salmon I've had in ages. The calamata olives were the perfect touch to bring out the rich flavor of the salmon without overwhelming it. I would highly recommend this fine Italian restaurant to anyone who enjoys a secluded romantic dinner. Only 15 tables, but you feel like you're the only tablein the world as the manager, servers, and busboys all have plenty of time to take care of your every need. Even though it's a half block from the 24th & Mission Bart station, you would never know it as the street is invisible from inside the dining room. Everyone should try this place at least once!
author: James N.

description:
I have been living in the mission for the last 5 years and every time a new restaurant pops up in the area it still has nothing on this place, it is the oldest italian restaurant in the mission almost 40 years old to be exact. La Traviata is a small but homey in the midst of the taqueria filled mission street.  

Italian food happens to be my all-time life-long favorite and this place does it like no other.  Everything is authentic and delicious from their pasta options to the veal dishes and even the seafood, I have tried nearly everything on the menu and have not been disappointed. (But definitely try the Lasagna! ) 

When it comes to old school atmosphere this place has it down. The walls are covered in signed pictures of opera singers that have actually eaten at the restaurant and some of the dishes are even named after them like the pasta alla Carreras, the Chicken Beverley Sills just to name a few.  

Not only is the food to die for but the service is also great, the waitresses are very sweet and knowledgable about both the food and wine and can give you some great recommendations if your on the fence between items, which you will be because everything sounds fantastic. Also, if you ask the older gentleman, Jack how long he's been at the restaurant he will have some amazing stories to tell you. 

This is one of my favorite places to come whether i'm taking my family from out of town or on a date, or even by myself to get something really quick, this is the place to go! 

And seriously, try the Lasagna, your stomach will thank you.
author: Jessica S.

description:
The environment at La Traviata is far removed from the rough neighborhood just outside its front door.  The decor can be described as picture frames.  They have a lot of pictures of what I assume are opera stars.

My meal of tortellini was just ok.  Well, I have never been blown away by tortellini so I didn't know why I thought this time would be different.  My brother's salmon was pretty good but again nothing mind blowing.  I would come back with friends but I probably wouldn't suggest it again if I were in charge.  I would probably order something else like the Vongole.

The service was extremely attentive as we were only 1 out of 3 parties in the restaurant that looked like it could seat 25 parties.  My glass of water was never empty.

I wish this place had more people.  It seems like a good lively neighborhood place to get a casual meal.  I hate seeing a decent restaurant with such sparse traffic.
author: John H.

description:
After a hectic day, my boyfriend and I stepped into La Traviata and immediately felt "at home." Its atmosphere was warm and welcoming.

Starters: Gorgonzola & walnut salad (4 stars) and Stracciatella soup (3 stars).

Entrees: Melanzane alla Vaness -- a layered eggplant, tomato, and moz cheese baked dish similar to eggplant Parmesan (5 stars) and Chicken Piccata (4 stars). The eggplant dish was seriously one of the best meals I've has in a long time. The flavors were pure, everything was fresh, and they were all cooked to perfection. 

Dessert: Tiramisu (5 stars) -- light and flavorful, not too sweet. 

Price: Not cheap, but reasonable and totally worth it. 

Service: Excellent
author: Megan F.

description: Delicious small good Italian restaurant try the tortellini the white sauce is to die for great small business will go here again waiters where nice and food was real good everything we ordered we liked.
author: Shaun S.

description: This place is great. If it is your birthday, they will give you a great birthday surprise! Service was exceptional. V good mom and pop Italian. Definitely get the Chianti, but above all the tiramisu tasted like a dream.
author: Allison F.

description:
I found this little place randomly while walking down mission st. I felt like I wasn't dressed well enough at first, but then I looked around and realized there was a mixture of attire amongst everyone. I was there around 6 on a weekday and it wasn't that crowded. 
The bread they give for the table was the best I've ever eaten, I still dream about it! If was baked fresh from the oven and brought steaming to our table. I couldn't keep my hands off it. I ordered minestrone soup, which was appetizer sized and really good. I also ordered a side of penne pasta with marina sauce, but they brought me tortellini instead. I didn't even care because it was so delicious! I ate every bite. My boyfriend got Alfredo tortellini that he also really liked. It was a little pricey for my liking, but worth it!
author: Emma G.

description: Consistently good Italian food. The bread is always piping hot and tastes really fresh. I recommend the seafood pasta.
author: Keito U.

description: After so many years, I'm pleased to say that La Traviata remains a very "homey" restaurant--cozy, with well cooked (and well presented) entrees.  I hadn't been in quite some time and last night I got together with a couple of my closest friends and I'm so very grateful to the restaurant, that they paced our meal, permitting us to enjoy and savor every moment of our dinner and company.  Thank you La Traviata!  We'll be back!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
(100th review. Yay!)

A friend's birthday party brought me to La Traviata and I found myself anamored by its traditional Italian charm. Long tables, white linen, pictures of family/friends/celebrities adorn the walls (perhaps untraditional but charming none the less), and the low playing opera music set an intimate yet casual mood. The birthday girl, who chose the venue, is very particular about ambience and hit a home run with La Traviata for a nice, classy yet down to earth meal with a few dozen of her friends. 

Yes, a few dozen. We roll deep! Which leads me to give another nod to La Traviata. I was impressed by how well our server attended to our table and the kitchen provided our food fairly quickly. 

I enjoyed the gnocchi with pesto sauce and a beet salad both of which were quite good. The ambience certainly trumps the food but it is by no means bad rather sits comfortable just above par. 

For an enjoyable, affordable, classy yet casual date or gathering make it La Traviata.
author: Quentin J.

description:
A hidden gem in the mission. Walking by you would have no clue that behind the unassuming entry way lay white table clothes, waiters in button down suites and low playing opera music.

My grandparents stumbled upon this place a few decades ago when they were in search of fresh soup and the entire family has since been converted. My favorites are the homemade bread and fresh minestrone soup. These items may seem like staples of any Italian restaurant but La Traviata far surpasses ordinary with these items. I swear by their soup. Seriously. Every time I get sick (which is frequently since I work with kids) I call up the Trav and order a pint to go. It works better and tastes better than overdosing on Emergen-C.

La Traviata is also a good place for group dinners. I always go at random times but have never had to wait for a table.
author: Johanna W.

description: Amazing authentic Italian food in the mission is a rarity but La Traviata is as authentic as it gets !
author: Vish E.

description: This place never disappoints, great food fine wine fabulous service. Not sure why people wait in line at other places when you can go here.
author: Marie H.

description:
Anyone who has given this place less than 5 stars must not know good Italian food! My father is Italian and places La Traviata on the top of his list for one of the best authentic italian restaurants. 
This place is great! You can tell it is a family owned business ( which makes me love it even more) and the setting is so romantic.
My parents and I have come to this place for years and have never left unsatisfied.
author: Danielle T.

description: I'm going to give thhem 4 stars out of 5.. I've really satisfied with price and taste of all the dishes especially pasta. However, Alla beverly sills is little bit salty that I expected.. That is why I've gave 4stars not 5.. Over all, wonderful place to go sometimes.
author: Bum P.

description:
A solid four stars and a bit of an anachronism in the Mission of 2012. La Traviata has been in business for 37 years and it looks and feels a lot different when you walk inside than pretty much anywhere else nearby. It's classically upscale and peaceful inside -- a nice respite from the average goings on in the Mission outside. 

An older gentleman (who I'm assuming was the owner) told me the best nights to go are Mon - Wed when there's less people there. I definitely enjoyed  having the place mostly to myself and will be back again soon.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I moved to SF in 2012 and my cousin (a former chef) said to me "There's a lot of great places in this area, but you HAVE to try La Traviata". Thus, began my love affair with this little establishment.

Try the prosciutto appetizer, the Beverly a la Sills, the La Traviata, and even the sweet breads.

Seriously, do not pass this place up.
author: Andres T.

description:
This place makes me wish I was in the mob.  

I would sit here all day, eat octopus in vinaigrette, slug down plates of pasta and lasagna all while planning the demise of a rival family or the next scheme that will earn me a ton of cash.

This place scores major points for atmosphere.

It feels like you've somehow stepped into someone's personal oversized dining room.  It's warm.  It's cozy.  There's Italian opera playing.  It's well lit but not too bright.  The seats are comfortable.  It creates a tranquil atmosphere that makes you forget all the loud buses, puke piles, trash heaps, taquerias and bacon dog carts on the street you just walked in from.

That wouldn't mean a whole lot if the food was crap.

Thankfully it isn't.

My first trip I got the aforementioned octopus in vinaigrette and loved it though the dressing was a bit much for the lettuce underneath.  Next I had the lasagna which was pretty amazing and since I'm a bit of a fan I immediately too the waitresses offer when she mentioned it was on special.  The pasta di mare is also a pleasure and thankfully comes with an appropriate ratio of seafood to pasta.  Oh and I'm putting the eggplant and cheese appetizer on my must have list.  Careful, it comes out super hot.  What it comes down to is that I've gone across the menu a few times and they do it right, even to the point that I've cleaned my plate with the bread.

Additionally, the service is great too.  Granted I haven't been in on a busy night yet but in any case my water glass stayed full and the servers were on top of everything.

The first time I came in here I figured I'd "treat" myself.  I think I'll be doing a lot more of that soon.
author: Steven R.

description: Discovered this place the other night.. SUPER cute inside. Has an inviting feel. Front of the house was a very nice older gentleman. Caesar salad and pasta was fantastic and reasonably priced. Already looking forward to my next visit!
author: Christa C.

description:
A friend's friend was in town visiting, so we all came out here for dinner on a Friday night. . Our party shared a couple of antipasto dishes--it was okay, nothing exceptional but always a great way to start an Italian meal. It was everyone's first time at the place and everyone seemed to enjoy the main dishes they ordered. Mine was the Gamberi pasta dish and it was yummy! 2 of the people in our party grew up on Italian Cuisine from NY and they approved of the meal.

If you're looking for a fancy, trendy, hip Italian restaurant, this is not it. La Traviata is more like the restaurant that your family has been going to for ages when you want some comfort Italian food and you always feel welcome and it feels cozy inside. At one point during dinner, all the lights went out, we thought it was a power outage due to the storms...it was actually someone's birthday so they turned off the lights to bring out a dessert (not sure what it was) with a candle and was playing a recording of a Happy Birthday song. That moment made me want to celebrate my birthday there! Definitely want to go back to this place again!
author: Barbra C.

description:
So sad to have to write this review. This once-awesome secret Italian delight has suffered horrifically in the past couple of years. The service and the food are unrecognizable, and worse, inexcusable. The one redeeming feature is an amazingly great caesar salad, almost worth its $9 price.

First: the service. One not very charming waitress for the entire restaurant. Same waitress we had bad service from a year prior. The older guy with almost all of his teeth filled our water glasses and tossed a plate of butter on the table when we arrived, but failed to bring bread. When we asked for bread, he brought it, and then yanked a loaf out of the basket and fondled it in his palm to show us it wasn't too hot to touch. Yeah, please dont put your big paws on my food? Does that actually have to be something you ask your wait staff not to do?

We ordered the caesar, antipasti misto, the bass entree and an old fave of mine, the a la beverly sills (chicken with prosciutto in a wine caper sauce). The antipasti was not fresh - it had clearly sat out for some time and the meat was dried at the edges. It was also obviously from a package. The cheeses were clearly pre-sliced provolone and mozarella from a jar, and flavorless. To cap it, the entire contents of the plate were floating in flavorless olive oil. 

Our meals came with small pre-plates of tortellini. zero effort at plating, and one plate had twice the pasta and sauce as the other. Oh, and the pasta tasted suspiciously, no, *convincingly*, like Lucca Deli's down the street's cheese tortellini and marinara sauce.

The bass, we were informed, was not actually bass but some other fish I've never heard of, but when it came out it looked and tasted a whole lot like cheap tilapia. It was breaded and drowned in a wine-caper sauce. My date ate two bites and decided she wasn't hungry any more.

The a la beverly sills ... sigh. The chicken breasts were cooked perfectly, but they were stuffed with what appeared to be raw american bacon. RAW. Not prosciutto. Did I mention it was raw? Beverly, rest her soul, would be affronted.

Most deflating is to discover that the italian chefs who used to populate the kitchen and venture onto the floor to generously chat with patrons are all gone. All that is left are local line cooks trying to churn out food they have no feel for. 

We spoke to the maitre d, and he comped our uneaten entrees, to his credit. We tipped on the full amount, making it $30 for a salad, a few Safeway coldcuts, 5 Lucca tortellini apiece, and a $5.75(!)  bottled beer each. 

Normally I'd want to give them a break in this economy, where everyone is struggling. EXCEPT - the place was inexplicably packed. They are not suffering for clientele, so I wonder if they are just investing less in the food and service and increasing their margins.

Just sad to see a great place lose its soul and its dignity.
author: Brooke B.

description:
Loved this place.  Fresh hot bread was at our table before we finished sitting down.

The gnocchi with rose sauce was amazing!  I love me some gnocchi and this one was really fabulous.  Wish the sauce had a little more kick to it but I can't complain..I ate every bite.  

The place is very cute inside...I would recommend for a nice cozy date night.  Not the best area for parking.
author: Lauren D.

description: I had walked by this place a lot of times and finally wandered in late on a Friday night. I couldn't find the hours posted outside so when we came in we asked how late they were open, only another 15 minutes or so. They were still super nice, and told us it would be totally fine as long as we ordered soon. They brought us bread which was delicious (we were also super hungry). I had bruschetta and gnocchi with pink sauce. Both were tasty and the gnocchi was some of the best I've had. I've had trouble finding an Italian place I love outside of NJ. This place is much more accessible than North Beach.
author: Christine H.

description: This place is where you go for an amazing authentic family-style Italian food. Ignore the crooked frames, because from the bread to the cheese tortellini, everything is melt in your mouth delicious. If Barretta is packed, don't fret, this place is a date night gem.
author: Bryce W.

description:
