As I walked through the mission, which was really an unpleasant experience, I found this place next to a friend market.  I walked in and felt like I was in a different world.  I was immediately greeted by ,who seemed to be, the owner.  i immediately asked if there was going to be opera, and he responded, "you're listening to it."  it was low and faintly heard, but I felt comfortable in the atmosphere.

There were so many choices to choose from really.  however, i went for the homemade lasagna.  I would have to say, it is going on my top go-to places for lasagna.  I will be coming back to enjoy other delicacies found here.  

La Traviata is really accessible from the Bart, another plus.
author: Sonja P.

description:
OMG! You know its Good when you walk In ..the owner greets you, he is Italian, his customers eating are Italian And at end Of meals he ask how much you loved it ,cause he knows you loved it!! I LOVED IT!! the night we were there ,there was about 3 birthdays ..so they turn off the lights only candles are lit And they played,happy birthday In Italian. The Food,bread, wine..all was amazing.
My husband And I Will be back for sure, we still talk about this being are fav. Part Of our 4,000 mile motorcycle ride!
author: Shirin T.

description:
We came here on a Sunday night for dinner, after another place we wanted to go to said there was an hour long wait. So, I looked up what was close by, and La Traviata came up! I figured why not, Italian food in the mission might be fun. 
We walked in and it is like walking into a time machine...old photos on the walls, beautiful vaulted ceiling, it was like eating in a wine cellar somewhere in Rome! 

The food was good, not amazing, but hearty, delicious, and filling. All entrees come with a side of pasta before the meal of course. And the bread was HOT and melted the butter just right. Yum! 

very basic wine list, but enjoyable. I had the sea bass, and it was very tasty, cooked just right, and flaked just perfect with the fork. 

everyone in our party was surprised when we were ALL happy with our food. Gotta mention the gnocchi, as they were perfect. like little pillows of potato happiness. The sauces were all wonderful. 

Service was friendly and prompt, and best of all, the bill was very reasonable. 

I will bring people here when they say they want Italian food. 

Thanks La Traviata!
author: Adrian M.

description:
Step out of the mission and into La Traviata.

The food, service, and prices were all right on the mark.
author: Ameer N.

description: I love this place. The food is always really good, the waiters are like real old Italian dudes, and it just looks like something straight out of the Godfather. The walls are covered in photographs and I'm pretty sure that the first time I went there, my friend and I were in the middle of dinner and all of a sudden all the lights dimmed and this crazy loud opera singer boomed out of the speakers the "happy birthday" song and then the waiters came out with some dessert for another table and the whole restaurant clapped. It was very dramatic. It's one of those memories that's so faint and I've told it so many times that I'm not sure if I made it up or if it's real at this point, you know? I'm hoping to go back there on my birthday this year and find out if it was real or not.
author: Erin A.

description:
Wow,
what a great restaurant. Having lived in the Mission for the last 12 years, I often walked by the restaurant wondering what it was like inside.  Regretfully, I have missed 12 years of eating at a great restaurant. I went with four friends. Everyone one raved about their food. The portions were large, delicious and not expensive. The service was fantastic. Oh yeah, the inside was great too, loved the wooden ceiling and all the photos covering the walls. My only complaint was not a fan of their Ceasar Salad with
the vinegrette dressing, but everything else surpassed my expectations.
author: Hal S.

description:
I chose this restaurant to celebrate New Year's Eve with my boyfriend and here's how it went.
This restaurant was a cozy little place in contrast to the alarming neighborhood just outside its doors. We were seated after waiting a couple of minutes, and then given our utensils then the menu to choose. I was somewhat disappointed in the menu only because I expected more to choose from, there was only about one small side of food and the rest were wine and drinks.

So we waited for our food, while enjoying some fresh bread and a glass of Merlot, and it didn't take long for it to arrive. The food was alright, I enjoyed my salmon and pasta, and my boyfriend seemed to enjoy his chicken. The service was friendly, considering there was only one female waitress bustling from table to table, and I give her props. She even ran after me outside when I forgot my lipstick on the table! We got a reasonable bill, nothing too expensive, and all in all it was a nice dinner but I probably wouldn't be coming back again.
author: Ludieann S.

description: Sadly, this restaurant used to be much better than it is now. We went for dinner last night and the waitress was very rude and didn't know the menu. She couldn't answer any of our questions and didn't check on our table at all during the meal. They also are apparently no longer serving pasta with their entrees which is a shame because that was a favorite.
author: Kelley B.

description:
Many that know me know that I have no problem complaining about food and/or service when I eat out. The beauty of this place is that I really have nothing to complain about. 

The food quality and flavor is excellent. The service is friendly, fast and not pushy.  The atmosphere is charming and tasteful.  I have eaten here twice, and I have to say that this is the best Italian food that I have had in San Francisco.  

I had a salad, lasagna and dessert.  The salad was a mixed greens with figs and goat cheese with a balsamic reduction dressing.  The goat cheese was lovely and mellow and the dressing just right.  The lasagna was wonderful.  It was of appropriate size and was not ramped up with silly "extra" ingredients like some places like to do.  It was just simple, as it should be.  No tricks, just lasagna.  The panna cotta for dessert, which was as smooth and delicious as one could hope for.

This is a little hidden gem in the Mission and I will be back again and so should you.
author: Scott A.

description:
I was sort of skeptical about eating here because the neighborhood was SCARY but I'm glad my uncle insisted because this place is a gem.

The bread here is HOT, fresh, and really soft (good for my 90 year old grandma). Grandma and I had the vongole (clams with linguine) which was absolutely perfectly cooked with lots of clams and a touch of wine. The portions are perfectly sized (not too large). I did not have any appetizers and had a bite of tiramisu (because they brought it out for my uncle's b-day).

I have to say the atmosphere and service was very charming. The staff was very warm and welcoming. The other patrons were also warm which isn't always the case when you have a 2 year old (my cousin) with your party. The owner made a half portion of "mac and cheese" just for him which was really good (I couldn't resist trying).

Turns out the neighborhood works because there aren't any tourists in this restaurant!!
author: Tricia K.

description: I love this place located in the mission it's a fantastic restaurant to go to. I was with a group of friends there last night as it was one of their birthdays. It was fabulous they even unexpectedly turned out the lights to sing her happy birthday with a tiramisu and a candle, the waiter must have heard me day to her that it was her birthday and randomly just thought of this kind gesture. Love the staff so warm and inviting.
author: Hannah P.

description:
I'm giving this place 3.5 stars. Oh how I hope to see the day when Yelp comes up w/ half stars! 

La Traviata is cozy and romantic. It's a cute little place located right along Mission & 25th-and definitely quite a change of scenery from the busy and bustling street it sits on.

The only way to write this particular review is in Pros and Cons:

Pros:

- The warm, doughy, straight-from-the oven, bread. Its delicious- and almost melts in your mouth.
- The red marina sauce- fantastic! I hate chunky tomato sauces, and this one is smooth and flavorful!
- The Beverly Sills Chicken. Tender, moist, flavorful, and oh so yummy! I would come back to La Traviata just for this dish!

Cons:
- The night we went I spent the whole meal slightly chilled. When I asked my boyfriend if he thought it was cold, and he said YES, I knew it wasn't just me. (The man is never cold!)
- One of the servers had terrible, terrible, body odor. It detracts from a nice meal.
- With the exception of my chicken, none of the food, as a whole, "wowed" me. If I'm going to go back somewhere for Italian food- Firenze by Night still gets my vote!

REALLY CUTE MOMENT: Two people in the restaurant were celebrating a birthday. At the end of the meal, they turned down the lights, played a opera-esque Happy Birthday song over the speakers, and brought the guests tiramasu with a lit candle. The whole restaurant clapped and wished them happy birthday. It was certainly a special customer service touch. :)
author: Annalise F.

description: Love this neighborhood spot with a simple classic menu at reasonable prices. Always amazing service. Try it!
author: Bradley H.

description:
La Traviata never disappoints!  

Saturday night was my birthday and I had a big race the next day, so Italian seemed like the right choice, and oh were we right!  From the Caprese, to the La Tosca chicken and tortellini, to the Creme Puffs and Spumoni ice cream, absolutely everything was delicious!
author: Susan C.

description: This has been our favorite restaurant for over 20 years. John continues Zev's legacy with the same warmth, class, and superb food.
author: P R.

description: I used to live right around the corner from this place and it was my favorite sit-down restaurant in the neighborhood. I've celebrated birthdays, new years, first dates, bon voyage parties, you name it at this place. I'm actually not a big fan of Italian food because it's often heavy but La Traviata gets it just right. This place is classy enough for a special occasion but affordable enough for a slackers wallet.
author: Albert S.

description:
I loved my experience here. I've been to lots of different restaurants in SF, at all different price ranges, and this one stands out for two reasons. 

1. The food is great. I got the Tortellini with Aurora sauce, which is a pretty safe bet. The sauce is creamy and packed full of flavor. The fried mozzerella is amazing, and the Calamari in Ink Sauce was pretty unique, albeit a little fishy for my taste. 

2. The service and authentic feel here was awesome. The owner (who was our server) is extremely personable. I came in right when the restaurant opened and he and the cooks were sitting around at a table chatting in Italian. He got up and immediately attended to us. A couple came in after us. The woman had forgotten her glasses so she was having trouble reading the menu. Moments later I see the owner walking out, wiping off the glasses which he had taken off his own face to loan to her to read the menu. 

I've been here twice and I know I'll be back for more. It's quiet, intimate, the service is great and the food is delicious and reasonably priced.
author: A H.

description: My family came in with special dietary needs & the waiter from Santa Rosa was very patient and took great care of us. She's one of the best I've ever encountered and definitely needs to be recognized for splendid service. Food was also good and they had unique desserts.
author: Tammy T.

description: Yum. It's hard to beat Italian pasta dishes for comfort food, but it is sad when it's bad. I had Pesto Gnocchi... so many ways that dish can go wrong; it was close to perfect here. The Gnocchi was perfect; the pesto worked well enough, tho it was of the standard food processed variety and not freshly hand-made (granted, you never find that in a restaurant). The rest of the dishes around our table were fantastic.
author: Kevin R.

description:
What a great little Italian spot in the Mission. For a friend's birthday, we were going to Medjool (nearby) for an event later that night and since La Traviata was nearby, she chose this restaurant for dinner.

Of course being the Yelper that I am, I did my research about the restaurant and was very excited for dinner that day. La Traviata has a great family owned feel to it - small, non-pretentious, and service is all provided by a staff who looks like family and friends. 

While I was here, I ordered the Alla Ricciarelli, which was a pasta dish consisting of chicken breast, caramelized onions, and cream sauce - yum, one of my favorite types of pasta dishes. The pasta was great - fresh, texture, taste and sauce was also very delicious.

Service was a bit slow the night we came, but I wont complain since we had a large group and they let us sit down even though half of our party showed up really late. I would definitely recommend La Traviata - great food, fair prices, friendly/genuine service, great little restaurant.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I visited La Traviata for a birthday dinner party and this "hidden gem" delivered a five star night..  I enjoyed the decor and the pictures of family and famous guests added a very personal and inviting touch.  The owners John & Silvia are such kind people who work so hard to make sure all of their guests have a wonderful evening.  The service was impeccable our waiter was on top of everything.

The food was some of the best Italian I have ever had.  The chicken piccata and tortellini with cream sauce were unbelievably delicious.  I look forward to many more visits to this amazing restaurant.
author: Meghan G.

description:
Come here for the Gnocchi...... My My, I won't forget the taste of those little dumplings for quite some time.

Love the Godfather style interior. Makes me think I should stroke the bottom of my chin with my fingertips when I walk in. 

Remember Gnocchi, because it's not personal,.... it's just business...eating business.
author: Mark B.

description: This place is awesome! The food was great! Traditional style food! Fresh bread! It is delicious. The service was amazing. My waitress, Sarah, made my time there very nice! If you're looking for a nice sit down meal, this is the place for you!
author: Lukas Z.

description: Love this place. Old school authentic. Crowd always pleasant, staff top notch. Great place to "get back to basics" when you've had too much if the trendy "next best thing".
author: Tim O.

description: We've been coming here for years. The menue has changed, and it is ever as pricey but now no side of tortellini (you have to order it a la carte). Also my BF had the clams linguine and had a lovely case of food poisoning the next day. I used to love this place but it's kinda gone down hill since the changes. Meh.
author: Halley M.

description:
Tried this place based on Yelp reviews, no one I know had heard of it, being tucked away in a part of the Mission that doesn't exactly bring to mind Italian restaurants.  I'm pretty picky about Italian food, and I thought this place was terrific.   Everything ordered was delicious, and while there are minor adjustments I'd make if preparing these dishes at home, for restaurant food, I thought it was very, very well done.  

Service was very good as well!  We arrived pretty late on a week night, and ordered just before the kitchen closed.  Even though it was already so late, they did not do anything to rush us.  We were surprised to look at the time when we were leaving, and the restaurant had been long closed.  They said nothing to us about it and were as nice as could be about us lingering past closing time.  

I will definitely be back again and will bring more friends!
author: Heidi M.

description: The menu is completely wrong, make sure to go to the restaurants website before coming. We were a little thrown off by the prices so be careful! Otherwise, La Traviata has fresh yummy bread, fast refills, and is a quiet and quaint place for family and friends.
author: Kristen M.

description: The gnocchi with pesto sauce was so satisfying and delicious. Probably the best gnocchi I've had in a really long time. The bread they give with the meal is awesome too. Fresh and warm, but try not to eat too much of it because it'll fill you up and you won't be able to finish your delicious meal! Seriously, get the gnocchi.
author: Rochelle I.

description: Some of the servers were very rude while I was at dinner with friends for a birthday. Not only were the servers rude but I got sick from eating there!!! I've been battling an upset stomach since this passed Saturday and  still feeling the effects of eating there.
author: Nichele R.

description:
Wow. This place has absolutely amazing food. 

I'm from the east coast. It's been very challenging to find Italian food in California that tastes similar to Italian food back home. This is the place. The food is truly fantastic. I don't know what else to say except to suggest that you go! I've eaten here several times and everything is wonderful.  I also love all of the pictures on the walls of famous opera singers and Keanu Reeves (no, I don't think he sings... but he did seem to eat at La Traviata once.) It feels very east coast, it tastes very east coast...."Mangia!"
author: Carolyn B.

description: Fresh pasta, delicious dessert, and such warm and friendly service! I would definitely recommend this place. It has such a homey yet romantic feel.
author: Claudia L.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant the entire meal was delicious! The bread is served warm and fresh out of the oven. Their fried mozzarella was the best I've ever had! I had the grilled chicken in balsamic vinegar the taste was so fresh! Best Italian restaurant I've been too! Service was great employees were so helpful and courteous!
author: Laura M.

description:
I really want to give this review 2.5 stars... but, essentially "Meh, I've experienced better."

Yes, the piping hot bread is a delight-- they give you a basket full so be careful not to fill up.

The waitress we had didn't know anything about Italian food and called one of the dishes I asked up about "yucky."

Gnocchi seemed to be the way to go and after ordering 2 plates of it the waitress returned to reveal they had  none because they sold out yesterday.  Yesterday?  If it's home made, why were there not more made Today?  Disappointed, we ordered the Carbonara, Tortellini, Chicken Beverly Sills, and Ai Fungi.

The Pancetta in the carbonara could have been crispier, and it was a little soupy but the linguine was clearly fresh.

Tortellini was definitley the best order-- really fresh, totally yummy but not outstanding from any other serious Italian restaurant.

Chicken was good but the steamed veggies it came with were lacking.

Ai Fungi looked like it came out of can.

When we asked the waitress for some red pepper she dusted it on herself-- something I think should have been left at the table and used at the discretion of the customer.

Service got really slow when the restaurant got busy.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Great experience here. Restaurant was surprisingly empty for a place with such high reviews (granted, it was a Tues night). There weren't that many servers so it was a little hard to get their attention, but they were so nice, very thoughtful and friendly.

Food was solid. I had the calamari pasta and my friend was able to 'customize' a vegetarian pasta to include mushroom rather than eggplant or something, and use olive oil. Was very nice of them to accommodate! 

My friend also asked for hot water and they gave her a nice little teapot for that. 

The bread was piping hot and soft. If I had come in with more of an appetite, I would have asked for more..

Pricing was very reasonable, at ~$18-20 per person all-in for an entree each. They also take reservations. Would come again!
author: Yan K.

description:
Wow, just noticed I last reviewed here 5 years ago.

Had a very pleasant dinner this evening.  Different ownership, I believe, but ambiance very similar.  We arrived early, 6:30'ish, so wasn't busy (was one-third full by 7:15).

Great stuffed (prawn/mushroom) Portobello mushroom special starter.  Eleven bucks or so and great for two of us sharing.

Chicken Florentina was perfect and generous portion.  Side veg a bit undercooked, and I like crunchy normally.  Tortellini side was just right size and very tasty.

Partner's Gnocchi w/aurora (pink) sauce was great.  

Above w/three glasses of mid-range wine $66 + tip.

Server and busser both very friendly and efficient.

A quiet little oasis right in the middle of the Mission - long may it continue.
author: David P.

description:
A charming Italian restaurant in the most unlikely of locations (24th and Mission). The ambiance was the highlight for me, wacky portraits cover the walls some signed, most featuring old haircuts and nice mustaches. 

Service was excellent and I couldn't help but notice the legit older Italian couple dining near our boisterous group (my apologies madam). 

The bread was served warm and was excellent, but the gnocchi wasn't the best I've had, the red sauce didn't have enough punch. For now I'll say 3 stars, but don't be surprised if I bump it to 4 stars after my next experience.
author: Jeremy S.

description: My first time eating here. (I had the alla carreras.) Spectacular and delicious no-frills Italian food! Homey decor, soft opera music,  great presentation, friendly service, open late, and the price can't be beat. What's not to love?
author: Richard C.

description:
The food here is decent but a bit toned down in flavor and creativity. It's the kind of Italian food your grandparents in Omaha might eat. The highlight is the free bread-warm sliced rolls that are perfect for cramming full of butter and then into your mouth. Overall, 3 star food. 

The staff are absolutely amazing. They were helpful, friendly, funny, and accommodating. Top notch!

For a friends birthday they turned down the lights, brought out tiramisu with a candle, and played a hauntingly cool operatic Happy Birthday on the speakers.  We don't know if was the staff or another guest but somebody with an amazing operatic tenor sung the last chorus aloud!  What an awesome experience and awesome service.
author: Ivan L.

description:
We came here for an early (by early I mean EARLY 5p) dinner and it was quiet and we had the place almost to ourselves. The waiter and hostess were super attentive and polite. We had the linguini with clams, fettuccine with chicken & carmelized onions, and the filet of bass. All were cooked to perfection (no overcooked chicken or fish!!), very simply but plenty of flavor. The linguini was very light, the bass had a great citrus freshness, and the fettuccine sauce was not overwhelmy creamy. The portions are not huge, but were satisfying. We also ended with the tiramisu, which was excellent. Not mushy, but very moist, and I loved additional chocolate sauce they drizzled.
Only faults I could have are the waiter who went out for a smoke and came back in smelling like it, and then the fact that the bathroom was tiny and had sticky floors... but the food was delish.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
I went there with several friends and ordered the eggplant entree. While good (but not great), it was about half the portion size of what I would have thought would have been acceptable, especially considering there was no side dish included. All of my friends who ordered pasta dishes got decent portion sizes.

I complained about this and was given a "Yeah, well, that's just the way it is" kind of response. So I ate more bread. (The bread, despite being apparently freshly baked, was just average "white bread." Something like an herbed focaccia would have been much better.)

But then maybe 15 minutes later, the server asks me if I'd like a side of pasta. Just to be clear, I asked if it were complimentary. She said yes. It's nice that they made up for the small portion size, but (a) they could have done it sooner (especially before I filled up on bread) and (b) they should just make the portion size of the eggplant dish commensurate with the other entrees.

Would I go back? Probably not. If you go, just don't order the eggplant.
author: Paul L.

description: Great place to eat! The food was wonderful we had the carbonara and gnocchi with pesto and both were delicious! The ambiance was very intimate. The staff was friendly. For dessert we shared the tiramisu and it was great!
author: Martin P.

description:
Solid. Is how I'd describe La Traviata. Also 'great value' come to mind. 

Lots of the good options (veal, eggplant, sausage). I've tried almost everything. 

The minestrone is rock solid. 

Prepare to be transported from Latin America (on mission st) into Italy, complete with old school photos and opera music. 

The service is terrific and staff super friendly. 

It's got history going back to 1975 (when they opened).

Best Italian in the Mission.
author: Ethan B.

description:
Great restaurant. I came here with my family and we were welcomed with a warm, "Hello!" as soon as we entered. As mentioned in other reviews, this restaurant has a very family owned feel. It is covered with paintings and pictures (some are signed) all over the walls. The restaurant is small but has a cozy feel to it that I really liked. 

The bread was really hot and fresh too. They served it to us with butter, but I also asked for a side of olive oil and vinegar. We ordered the eggplant appetizer as well as the fried mozzarella. The eggplant was good, but the mozzarella was definitely amazing! My mother ordered a minestrone soup which was so-so. Not bad, but nothing too exciting. I ordered a lasagna that was part of their dinner specials for that day. That was superb!

All in all, I loved this restaurant! It's not too busy, they are open late, and the food is great! Come here!
author: Angelica V.

description: Super old fashioned - way different scene inside than out on Mission Street. Feels like an old Little Italy restaurant. The bread was too hot - but yummy - almost biscuit-like. The gorgonzola honey salad was great. The pink sauce over tortellini - good! And great tiramisu. I'm too full.
author: Andrew K.

description: Wonderful food, great service and a lovely atmosphere -- excellent old-school San Francisco charm!
author: Gina F.

description:
What a hidden gem. 

I love discovering secrets. Now... just because I tell y'all how good this is... doesn't mean you can tell the WHOLE world and then it gets too popular for me to randomly pop in and get my grub on... 

anyway. This spot is everything good. Like some of the other reviewers here, it definitely has a "grandma's living room" vibe to it. It's homey, without feeling dirty or too casual. The white table cloths, candles, and fresh roses on every table don't make me angry either. Everything is classy and humble... From the family and celebrity photos on the wall, to the lemon in your ice water. 

and the FOOD?! Oh man, if there was such a thing as TOO good. I had the cheese tortellini with white cream sauce and it was fantastic. The only thing that was better... was eating the leftovers later that night and discovering they were still AWESOME. My friend ordered the lasagna special and it looked beyond good as well. 

The bread is fresh and super hot out the oven. If you have the nerve to complain about it, you're silly in your face place. 

Will definitely be returning to this pleasant surprise. :)
author: Katelyn L.

description:
We went here for my birthday on a Monday. As expected, the place was not busy and the service was prompt, courteous and very flexible! I mean, the waitress was good-natured, a good conversationalist and had very good suggestions.

First of all, the bread they brought for us was as fresh and as delicious as I have ever had. Very crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside! We ordered the eggplant parmigiana and the tortellini (in a cream sauce) which were both the best I have had. I also ordered a latte which was very good.

Lastly they brought out Tiramisu for my birthday (with a lit candle and turned the lights off! Yay! I felt like a little kid :). It was delicious and a must have if you come out here.

Five Stars and a definite must-try!
author: Bharath I.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for what I hoped would be a fun date night. Didn't quite work out that way.
The only thing standing between this place and the dreaded single star was our appetizer, the stuffed eggplant with caprese. Succulent, not drowned in balsamic like the salmon I ordered for my entree.  Her chicken al Tosca was progressively worse with each bite, the steamed vegetables that came with each of our dishes were bland, and one of the servers had particularly noxious BO. Nowhere near worth the nearly $30 we each dropped before getting the hell out of there as quickly as possible.
Bottom line: I don't know if we came there on an off night, or if the whole place is really that bad and the rest of these reviews are deluded, but...yeah. Pretty much at the bottom of our list of places to return to.
author: Scott L.

description:
We went because of the Yelp reviews, and they were spot on! 
The ambiance, the service, the food and the friendly atmosphere all added up to: "We'll be back!"
author: John H.

description:
I had walked past this little joint forever on the way to and from the BART and never paid any attention.  One night the boyfriend and I decided for date night we would love Italian.   I spent a month in Italy last year and get a hankering for good Italian food often and all I have to say is hell yeah!!  

This place is amazing.  The ambience cannot be beat....it's lovely and elegant without being stuffy.  The staff is incredibly helpful and friendly and knowledgeable.

I would have oved to have ordered an appetizer but with the amazing fresh bread that we were served that had just came out of the oven, there was no need.  

We each ordered an entree...one calamari entree and I had the salmon in parchment paper that they open at the table.  Let me first say that you receive a serving of cheese tortellini with your choice of sauces.  AMAZING......may I suggest the pink sauce?  Perfect for dipping that amazing bread into.  And my salmon...with the olives, capers and other deliciousness that was in that paper it was just enough food.  And every bite brough me immediately back to eating while I was in Italy.  Simple, clean fresh flavors and ingredients.  

La Triviata is the perfect spot for a date or a family or group outing.  We will be back as much as possible.  La nostra sera a La Triviata era perfetta!
author: Brent R.

description:
If someone asks me where to go eat in the Mission if they didn't want Mexican, Chinese, or American, mid-priced, with a classy and romantic ambiance, and excellent food, I would definitely say La Traviata! 

This is the first restaurant that has managed to wow me in a long time! 
When we were looking for it and saw their small (with amazing lettering) sign, I immediately thought small and normal.... 

WRONG. well not entirely. This place is so much bigger inside, with a very nice decor. The insides make you feel like you are in a small family-owned restaurant in Italy. It was like a spell. For one hour, I seriously thought I was not in the Mission! or San Francisco! 

There are only 2 workers. Very nice old gentlemen. From the looks of it, it's a father-son gig. 

We sat down and waited kind of long for the bread, but it was totally worth it because it was fresh, pipping hot, and homemade bread. Delivered straight to our table from their kitchen. It was the BEST BREAD & BUTTER I have ever tasted in my whole life! (plus when we said we wanted to take it home, he kindly wrapped it and gave us extra!! chyea) 

The food was nothing less than excellent! 

My favorite is their special Pasta di Mare with white cream sauce. I expected only to finish half of it cause I don't usually like creamy that much. WRONG AGAIN. Their cream sauce is creamy yet not sickeningly. everything is just right!!! 

and just when is everything just right?! But this place somehow did it! 

If you want to impress a friend, date, boss, or whatever complicated thing you are in, take them here! Your night will be better! Mine was. :)
author: Miss C.

description:
This place passes two key tests for me:

They have good hot bread, and always refill the bread basket without you having to ask; They refill your water without you asking, and you never have an empty glass of water.

Unfortunately the food doesn't live up to such lofty expectations, which isn't to say that it's horrible; it's just that the food doesn't live up to expectations.

Got the antipasto starter with the girlfriend, and the mortadella slices were just a little too thick for my taste...the mozerella was solid, but too little of it. Proscuitto (if that's what it was) was also a little too thick, the salami was good!

The girlfriend got the veal scallopini, and I got the basa with white wine lemon caper sauce...The fish was cooked perfectly, the but the coating was not good at all; the wet batter that the fish was fried/cooked in got soggy and messy when the delicious sauce was poured (quite liberally might I add) all over it. The Veal Scallopini's sauce was too similar to my fish's for me to taste a difference.

Overall, a good solid place to come to. Hope you like opera :music cause there's a lot of it!
author: David H.

description:
Italian food in the mission... I shouldn't have had such high expectations. 

Service gets an A+ and it makes me compelled to make this four stars but unfortunately, the food was only average. I can understand the local appeal of the place given there are not very many italian options and it is good enough, but it is not something I would make a separate trip for.

My group got: Al Funghi pasta with cream sauce, Eggplant Parmagiana, Chicken Parmagiana, Veal Parmagiana (we're creative, I know), and Tortilini with pesto sauce. We also got bruschetta for appetizer in addition to the piping hot bread they serve as soon as you get there. Everything was pretty average, nothing stood out. 

Prices are fair (typical pasta dish is 10-15) and they give a generous serving of wine.
author: Raina B.

description:
I don't know if it was an off night or a bad night but this place was pretty terrible. The cream in my dish was too watery, the gnocchi was too soft (overcooked?), and the calamari dish didn't really have a strong calamari flavor. 

Did I mention the service was horrible? We waited a god hour for food. 

I assume the waiter was straight Italian but when I asked for the check while my friend was still eating (we had a movie to catch), he gave me some lip about asking for the check while was the lady was still eating and then didn't bring us our check ever. I had to ask the other waiter for it. It's cool that your traditional, it's honestly a plus, you can comment and make me feel guilty but still bring me the check. It's only because i thought what would take 30 minutes to get our food took almost an hour that I was in ANY rush at all. 

I honestly think this place with more staff would be a lot better off but my experience was terrible.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Update: I've been back since my first review, and La T is just as charming, delicious, and inviting as ever.

The only thing better than the food here is the service - and I wanted to (re)emphasize that they provide some of the best customer service I've experienced in the city. A rare treasure indeed!
author: Sam S.

description: Made a reservation for a Saturday night at 6pm, thinking they might be busy....boy was I wrong! The place is kind of sleepy and quiet, but the food was pretty tasty. Like other reviewers noted, the bread is sensational. We also ordered the antipasti plate, which was a little weak but not too bad. I had the gnocchi with pesto, it was good but a bit heavy. My bf had some sort of seafood pasta dish, but the muscles were lacking majorly. Our waitress was really nice and polite and the food came out pretty fast. It was a nice meal but not something I'd rush back to SF for.
author: Ali W.

description: I wish I could give this place an extra star....Last night a friend took me to this place. Very cute mom and pop restaurant. It reminds me of the lady and the tramp restaurant scene in the movie....authentic and romantic. Great wine, food, and my God the service was just fantastic. Must revisit, VERY soon!!!!
author: Tal P.

description:
A friend and I had dinner here on a week night and I was delighted
to find parking in the same block and the restaurant nearly empty.
Service was excellent and I enjoyed  our meal.  Had I not just returned from a recent visit to Rome and a thirteen day cruise in Italy, I probably would have been even more enamored with everything!

It was all delicious, though, and in portions large enough to share.  My seafood pasta was excellent and I loved the Melanzane Imbotitte, grilled eggplant  with mozzarella. balsamic and tomatoes.  I was impressed with the wine list and many of the selections were very reasonably priced.  We drank a red - a 2006 Antigua Santadi, $28, that was most enjoyable.  I've had better tiramisu, however.

The dining room was a little dark, covered in pictures of past diners, stained glass and opera played in the background.  I might have been at La Scala in Milan.

It was a lovely evening and I can't wait to return!
author: Carmen H.

description:
Hard to find good Italian food in the neighborhood, and this one's the closest to home. 

Our bread was kind of burnt, but after slapping on that butter, it was almost perfect. 

There were three servers on the floor. Two of them were nice and smiley, and the third one was very robotic-like and not too friendly.

The food was legit. I got the linguine with the manila clams and they were very generous with those clams! Tried my mom's chicken - GOOD! and my cousin's pasta with creamy sauce - YUM!

There were a few birthdays going on and they'd blast the happy birthday song. My mom told one of the servers it was my birthday too, but they didn't play the song for me. I was kind of relieved because I didn't want everyone staring, but at the same time disappointed because they did not acknowledge me! Even a candle on my dessert would've been nice. :(

We were seated in the back of the restaurant, and when we got home, realized our clothes smelled like food. I really hate smelling like food. Good thing we weren't dressed in our finest duds like everyone else was.
author: Zell C.

description:
This is a nice place. Old-school, classy, not too glitzy. The food is decent, though there are better. I ordered calamari and they were pretty good. I actually think I liked the tortellini with cream sauce more, though. My wife ordered chicken and vegetables. Again, OK. 

You're not going to get a super fancy experience than at other joints. You will get a more classic, intimate experience. The food is not not as imaginative, but that's not necessarily a negative. Some of the "better" Italian places in the city are creative, but end up disappointing.
author: Aaron N.

description:
I never had gnocchi before so I was excited to see it on the menu. Since the waiter recommended the gnocchi over the squid ink pasta I was also thinking about, I selected the gnocchi with pesto. Unfortunately, the gnocchi was far what I had imagined. It was very thick and sticky and mushy... perhaps that's how it's supposed to be, but the way too creamy pesto took it over the top. I couldn't taste the fresh, basil flavor in the pesto at all because it was just so rich. Disappointment!

The bread, however, was a nice starter - not any special flavor or anything, but it comes hot with a deliciously crispy exterior.
author: Elaine L.

description:
I loved the interior decorating first of all. The inside of the restaurant, paired with the traditional italian music, really created the general atmosphere. It made me want to go straight home and watch The Godfather! which is exactly what I did!
I ordered the breaded mozzarella & marinara for an appetizer, it tasted just as good as mozz-sticks, but was bigger, and smothered in sauce.  The bread was hot, and delicious. Tasted freshly baked, and the butter melted right in front of my eyes.  I ordered the prawns and tomato sauce, which was amazing. My only complain was that I prefer angel hair, and they only had regular sized noodles.  My girlfriend got the carbonara, bacon and cream sauce.  We were both beyond satisfied with the whole experience. Best italian we've had outside North Beach! I'll definitely go here again!
author: Jevir G.

description:
It's very likely I will not be back.  I've written over 100 reviews and have only given one 1-star review and one 2-star review.  The rest have all been 3's, 4's and 5's.  

Basically it takes A LOT for me to post something negative.  

This place would've probably received one less star if it weren't for the food, which was actually good.  

I've worked in the restaurant industry (and in many service positions) and no matter how slammed you are, the cardinal rule in a venue that serves food is to acknowledge your table and check in whenever possible.  Especially in a small square layout of a restaurant where it's very easy to spot any table and see your patrons. 

How our night went: 

Host (who was friendly) greeted us and asked us if we had a reservation.  We said no.  Told us wait would be 15 minutes.  We said that's fine.

So far ok, not a problem.

Fifteen minutes later we get seated.  

Still things are alright.

Server takes a really long time to get to us.  Understandably, b/c looked like there were only 2 waitstaff in the entire place.  She apologizes for the delay in getting to us and takes our order.

At this point, we're still alright.

Looooooong time goes by.

We get water.

Loooooooooooong time goes by.  

We get bread.

Table next to us, also equally ignored, does not have salt at their table and since our server is no where to be seen, asks us if they can borrow ours.

We FINALLY get our food.  At this point we've gone through our bread basket and I ask for another one.  

I think our server forgot b/c again a looooooong time goes by and we don't get it.  I then ask the only other server around if we can get bread.  

Again some more time passes (do you see a pattern here?) and we still have no bread basket.  At this point I'm already 2/3 done with my dish.  The point of asking for the bread was to dip the bread in the pesto sauce that came w/my gnocchi.  

Second basket of bread finally shows itself.

By now, me and my friend are tired and ready to go home.  It's already been over 90 minutes, and for a party of two, it's lengthy.  Especially considering all we ordered was one soup and two entrees.  We didn't order any drinks or dessert.    

Again, no sign of any server.  Try several times, as we had for the bread basket, to flag someone to our table, to ask for the check, but we continue to be COMPLETELY ignored.  We were at the point of just leaving cash on our table and walking out the door when our waitress, who has still ignored us, starts to take orders  from the table next to ours (not the table that asked for our salt, but the table on our other side), and then we're, 2 hours later, able to pin her down to get our check.

The service was not unfriendly, just non-exsistent.

If you have a lot of time, you will probably be ok with La Traviata, b/c as I said before, food's good.  But if you're like me, and would appreciate some form of service and not want to spend 2 hours in a restaurant for a simple meal, then I would definitely not go to this restaurant on a Saturday night.
author: Swetha G.

description:
Okay i did not expect my day to be so good. I first went to another Italian restaurant not far from here, but the place was so crowdy that we decided to find another Italian restaurant nearby and OMG are we lucky to find such great place not far from my apartment! The place is quite hidden because the sign of the restaurant is pretty small. But man when you get in here, it feels like youre not in Mission street anymore. The place has dim lighting and they have portraits of artists all over the wall...its really good for close friends to hang at this place. The service was just great, they are kind and always fills your water up when its finished. The food....MIGHT i say wonderful. They serve home made hot breads, so whenever you eat the breads, it taste really good and fresh! 

We ordered various foods:
-Baby marinated octopus(It was in the appetizer section)
-Torrellini Alla Romana(exquisite, i love their creamy sauce)

I was really satisfied with this place. Def gonna come here again when i am craving for a good Italian food. Whats not to like? Overall, the service was great, the food were scrumptious and the ambiance is just cute! LOVE it.
author: Cavin T.

description:
Great old school ambiance.
Great Italian cuisine.
Excellent service.
Excellent Value.
Best taramisu i've ever had.
Everything is made from scratch in the restaurant.
Best bread in the city.
author: jeffy e.

description: 2.5 stars. Our waitress was super sweet and I especially appreciated when she asked the kitchen to make me pesto I could eat, since I couldn't eat the kind with cream, but the pesto was not that remarkable. The gnocchi was good. The grilled eggplant with melted mozzarella, diced tomatoes and basil flecks also good. The food didn't wow me. The portions were small. There are better Italian restaurants for the price.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: My family and I absolutely love this place. The food is amazing and the service is great. The lobster linguini and lasagna are the best!
author: Janelle K.

description:
I found this place on Yelp and decided to try it out. You really cant find much Italian food in the mission and i am always looking for a fix. The place was cute and cozy. The service was great and attentive. The food was over priced for what it was. 

The Mozzarella stick were yummy, the eggplant was good, but no sides, just fried eggplant for 13$. and we had a special chicken dinner that was 18$ and not that great and the wine sauce was bland. This meal came with a side of tortellini in choice of sauce. We picked the cream sauce and that was the best part of the meal. 

If the prices were cheaper i would go back. But for what we paid for the meals was not worth it.
author: Heather P.

description: It was a Friday evening around 730-8ish, me and one of my best friends were looking for Italian places to eat around the mission area because I was craving and I wanted to go somewhere I've never been before. Walked into a couple of restaurants by the help of yelp but unfortunately the wait was too long for impatient stomaches. We stop by Phat Phillies restaurant to say hi to his friends. One of them recommended La Triviata and boy did we hurry there (at this point we were starving). The entrance was really low key and a little endearing. Walked into a cute little waiting area where you can sit down and look at the menu until they seat you. "Table for two?" Said the kind host and then he proceeded to seat us onto a table. All I see around me are painting and photos of what seems to be family, mixed with cultural art. So beautiful. The waiter came to take our order but I had a couple of questions about the menu and he answered all of them with an assurance that he understood my question trying to answer it as best as he could. The service was amazing and the food came quick! Okay, here we go. THE FOOD- let me just say I'm a hint of Italian so it explains my weekly craving for the delicacies and I've had my fair share of Italian cuisine. This place, by far, hands down has one of the best, tender cooked chicken I've ever had with some bomb pasta and the creamiest sauce exploded in my mouth. Accompanied by La Rossa of course, woah party. Ah, satisfied but sadly too full to try dessert, thank God for next time. My favorite part is that it's not too loud in there. Everyone respects the quiet atmosphere. Great service, great food! What more can you ask for! Plus I went to the bathroom and I was always told that when in a bathroom of a restaurant, check the cleanliness. If the bathroom is clean than most likely the whole place is. And it was! Five stars! Love this place and will be back sooner than soon!
author: Stephanbright G.

description:
If I get to choose a last meal on earth, it'll be here.

Mozarella en Carrozo!  Squid pasta thing ("the tinta!")  So Good!
author: Ben V.

description:
This is a nice little place in the Mission.  I stumbled upon it using the Monocle feature of the Yelp app while walking around the Mission District.

The food was really good, especially the bread.  The prices were about what you would expect for nicer, authentic Italian dishes.  Service was decent, could have been a little better I'd say.
author: Joey Y.

description: Love this place! Such a nice place to go to for a special event. The food is amazing and so tasty. The ambience is so nice and slightly romantic. It is slightly pricey but definitely worth the price.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
This is the easiest-to-miss restaurant in the Mission. It's also one of the best.

I took a friend of picky Italian stock with me. He was not impressed by our admittedly slow ordering time. However, the waitress came over and apologized at length, causing my friend to say, I quote: "Complete recovery!" The bossman came over and devastated my friend with far superior Italian, to which my friend asked if the Three Tenors ever swung by, and the bossman directed him to three photos of the Three Tenors directly beside our table. 

Shut the door and hold the horses!

And the food? My take is most Italian food can be made better and for a lot less money at home--but not here. Fresher, better, homier--it really is terrific. The lasagna blended chicken with beef and raisins, and was among the best lasagnas I've ever had. Wonderful bottle of Montepulciano vino. Desserts were spectacular. The bill was astonishingly small.

I am thoroughly in love.
author: matt s.

description: I can't understand all of these high reviews.  The service was fast and relatively attentive - 4 stars - but the food was 2 stars.  This is like a 1970s throwback, in terms of decor, ambiance, and food.  Strange to have this here in the Mission's Gourmet Ghetto.  The octopus was not fresh and had a strange texture - perhaps it was from a can or a jar.  The shrimp was slightly old and the pasta with it was so bland that I decided to take most of it home and doctor it with my own spices.  (Salt alone couldn't compensate.)  Yes, there's hot bread, but it's like Wonder Bread with a harder crust.  I won't be returning.
author: Sumomo O.

description: The best thing about this place is they are located in Mission and they have delicious food!! I visited here both as a group and as a couple, and we always received a great service. Clam Spaghetti is amazing with reasonable price. Their bread is yummy. Casual dress attire is okay here. Definitely and definitely recommend this restaurant:)
author: Maitai N.

description:
went here for birthday dinner. It was suggested by my brother. It's small. It's in between taquerias. They have the hottest bread I've ever had. Just put the butter in and watch it melt. Also, it tastes really good. I had the chicken tosca special which was chicken breast with a provolone wrapped asparagus in the middle. It was all moist and served with steamed vegetables witha side of tortellini ($17.95). We also had the calamari which was the fresh kind, not the breaded and deep fried and the eggplant which had cheese on it. 

The meal was really good and the wine was reasonably priced. Would definitely go back here if in the area and in the mood for Italian.
author: Andrew Y.

description: We went on a Sunday night. It is a CLASSIC italian place that is well worth your time. Bread brought out HOT with good butter. Best cioppino I have had. Also the gnocchi was terrific. Don't skip it if you have a chance
author: Jacob Z.

description: To say good-bye to an old friend, we invaded La Traviata tonight.  When he asked the restaurant if he could host a large party at one of his favorite restaurants (he had taken most of us there in sub-groups), they just recommended he do it on a Tuesday night. And so we did.  It was chaos (24+ people in 2/3rds the restaurant).  But it was wonderful.  The bread was served piping hot right after most people had sat down given they had asked when to bring it out.  The entrees came out a bit haphazardly, as also compounded by our multiple seating rearrangements by then, but the servers adapted well.  The service was always friendly.  They tolerated our raucous with pleasant smiles.  It was really like having a dinner party in a family home.  They were also willing to subdivide our check which was great.
author: Anne K.

description: This place is amazing. I'm always so surprised it isn't packed when I go there, but at least it's always easy to get a table. The food is amazing here. The Gnocci is probably the best I've ever had. It's a bit rich though so I suggest getting a gnocchi and one other dish and splitting them between two people. The Caprese salad is one of my favorite starters. Also, save some of the warm fresh bread they serve you to dip into all of the amazing sauces!
author: Kyle J.

description:
Great place to savor a slow Italian meal on a Friday night!

My husband and I had a date night here back in June. The bread with delicious, as noted by the other reviews. DH had a chicken with asparagus dish that he enjoyed (forgot the name), and I liked my pasta with mushroom (again, forgot the name). We would come back here.
author: L. M.

description:
I have lived in the outer Mission, about 5 minutes from La Traviata, for the past 13 years and went there for the first time about one week ago with my friend Cherise and my boyfriend.  Cherise recommended this place to us, as she used to live just upstairs from the dining room.  

I guess I never went in there because I was wary of the one Italian restaurant in the Mission!  When I entered the restaurant, I was immediately overcome with the feeling of being in the dining room of an old Italian couple!  There was a very inviting ambiance and the servers were super friendly.  

Now onto the food...OOOHHH THE FOOD!  Well, I knew, based on the environment, that the food would be more extravagant than simple spaghetti and meatballs, but to say the food was 'better' would be a gross understatement.  I ordered the "Chicken Beverly Sills"...This dish was named after the famous Opera singer who ordered this dish regularly on her visits to this 38 year old restaurant.  My boyfriend had the Chicken Fiorentina...another amazing dish.  They have specials regularly that will make your mouth water at their mere mention!  

My boyfriend and I came back with his parents and little brother 2 days later and tried a few more items on the menu...the salmon and the panna cotta dessert are my personal recommendations, but everything thus far is simply delectable. 

So, if you find yourself in the Mission, and want to treat yourself to an amazing, home style Italian meal, head to La Traviata between 24th and 25th streets.  Gustoso.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I love hidden gems, and La Traviata is definitely a hidden gem in the Mission.  Who would expect such a high-class place to be a block from the 24th Street BART station?  It's classy in a comfortable way.  I've eaten here probably five times, going back frequently with friends from out of town.  My neice was a year old when we came, and she loved singing along with the opera music (she was quiet about it, though, honest!).  I've only made reservations once - it's always been easy to get a table.  

I love the piping hot bread they bring to your table, and the service is fantastic.  Cream sauces aren't usually my thing, but it's their specialty - you've got to try the tortellini with cream sauce!  Personally, my favorite dish is the pasta with Italian sausage - plenty for dinner plus lunch the next day.  Spicy and good!  Tiramisu here is yummy, too - worth saving room for!  

Check this place out if you want a nice Italian meal in the Mission.  Yes, there is such a thing!

Update: I just came back from another outstanding meal at La Traviata this evening (4/30/2008).  Fried mozzarella, fresh hot bread, lasagna (a special this evening), tortellini with cream sauce, Pasta Ai Funghi (with mushrooms), tiramisu, and profiteroles.  All delicious.  Even their mocha is fantastic.  I love the service.  This place just makes me happy!
author: Michael I.

description:
This is definitely homey Italian food.  The restaurant is very old-world, maybe a little cheesy but I thought it was cute (pictures all over the walls, dark wood, very friendly old man waiters).  The menu selection isn't enormous or innovative but I had a great spaghetti ai funghi (perfect tomato sauce and loads of mushrooms).  My mouth is watering right now.

My insalata mista was fine and the panna cotta was ok - I've had better - but I left a happy customer and I'd definitely come back.
author: Priscilla T.

description: I thought the portions were a little small, but the food tasted great. They wait staff is also really friendly and helpful. We felt a little under-dressed in tshirts and jeans.
author: Chase L.

description:
The food here is amazing!  The bread is so delicious - hot, crispy, and fluffy.  It was very addicting.  They also shaped the butter into tiny balls, that melted into the bread.  Next up was the tortellini with pink sauce.  That sauce is so good that we started dipping the bread in it.  And there was plenty of bread for us to consume after finishing the our meal.

The basa filet was flavorful, with white wine, lemon, and capers giving it a zing.  The Ai Fungi spaghetti also had the pink sauce, with tomatoes, mushrooms, and garlic.

The staff was friendly and efficient.  The walls were covered with photographs and opera was playing lightly in the background.  It's definitely like a different world with amazing food.
author: Rose C.

description: A restaurant from the godfather hidden in between taco shops in the mission. Good food, good value cool ambiance.  If you want no pretense italian food in the mission come here.
author: Mike I.

description:
I'm always on the hunt for great Italian food in San Francisco, and had yet to be impressed with the sprinkling of restaurants I'd tried in the city. Then one hungry night, thanks to Yelp, I realized I was living practically on the same block as la Traviata and had never even noticed it was there! 

The interior is dark and lovely...photos of great singers and staged operas cover the walls. There is a small but attentive waitstaff...they seemed a little flustered the night we came in, and I got the feeling maybe they were down one person that night. I guess I took one star off just for feeling a little rushed through the whole dining process. But then, the food...

First, the warm crusty bread. I was eating it and it tasted so good it felt like sinning. I looked at my handsome boyfriend from over top of my last crusty bite of bread and wondered if maybe I loved that bite more than him...

Everything else was delicious too...we ordered a seafood pasta and raviolli in tomato sauce. The quality of the food and the dining experience here are a bargain at the prices they charge. I can't wait to come in again for round 2! Best homestyle Italian I have had on the West Coast yet.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Traditional Italian cuisine  bruschetta appetizer to die for the bread was hot and good  we had tiger prawn entree and veal parmigiana  both were excellent   The service was personal friendly and efficient -- Oh and if you are an opera fan -- lots of pictures to look at .. 
Would recommend this to anyone  less than a block from 24th &mission Bart
author: D D.

description:
So good! Walked in, thought I was not dressed up enough.

The food was pretty goooood. The chianti was yummy. Service was nice and we got a lovely table.

Friend forgot wallet, and got free ice cream the next night when he went back to pick it up.

I look forward to coming to this place again!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Wow, a total hidden gem in the Mission. I was craving good pasta and came here based on Yelp reviews. It was so good we've been twice now. 

I ordered the fungi pasta the first time and the tortellini tonight. My girlfriend had the gnocci in aurora sauce and the gamberi. All of the dishes were really superb - some of the best pasta I've had in a long time. The fresh bread was lovely too.

The decor is a bit dated - lots of wood panelling and booths - but I kinda enjoyed the homely feel it gives the place. Service was wonderful and the meals were great value for money.
author: Bella D.

description: Nice little Italian place right in San Francisco.  It is a great place to get away from the tourist traps and not far from the middle of downtown!  Great food, service was excellent!  Tables are classy and elegant, attire is casual, noise level is quiet, and we didn't have to wait at all on a Thursday night at 8:00!  I'm not from San Francisco but if I go back I'll definitely be back to La Traviata!
author: Dustin B.

description: Best Italian in the city!!  Get ready to go back to a little old school with photo's, wait staff and menu  from decades gone by... just the type of slow retreat I love in a bustling city.  It's cute and a very unexpected surprise in the heart of the Mission!
author: Amber D.

description: Amazing food and fantastic service in a comfortably cozy environment. 7pm on a saturday and the place was empty. Within 35 min it was packed!
author: Michael C.

description:
This used to be my favorite place to take visitors from out of town, and the occasional in-town friend or date who has never heard of it. I will not be returning. Apparently, there's been a change in staffing, and the new folks have no idea what they are doing. 

On a recent weeknight, with the place half empty, my friend CONSUMED all of his courses twenty minutes (and two or three inquiries)  before I even RECEIVED my first course. I ordered the salmon, which I had ordered many times there before, so i knew it did not take two hours to prepare. 

I told the waiter upon arrival that I was starving. We both told him to bring the food "as it is ready". Another guy (waiter? host? busboy? manager? One never knows at this place) also waited on our table, which seemed to only confuse matters. The two of them wasted way too much time making pleasantries rather than attending to our basic need: for food. After I had eaten half the bread basket while waiting for my meal, the waiter asked, with obvious expectations of a positive response, "Do you feel better, now that you have filled up on bread?" I wanted to reply, "I will feel better when my dinner gets here," but I bit my tongue. 

I watched my friend eat his first course as I gnawed on bread and talked. Then they brought his second course, and I kept looking up expectantly, waiting for mine. Everyone else in the restaurant was getting their food except me. 

I asked three times about my entree. Finally, one of the waiters said he would get it right away. Apparently that was when he put the order in, for I waited another 30 to 40 minutes before it was finally brought to me. 

The two gentlemen appeared to have no idea that anything was wrong with the way in which they served our table. I caught the attention of a third server when I was giving up hope of ever seeing my food, and she later told me that she asked the first two what had happened with my order. They explained to her that my order came so late because it was an entree, and therefore must not come until the appetizers, soups, and pastas had been consumed. They did not even consider that the appetizers and soup were being consumed  solely by my friend, and that he had not ordered an entree. They did not consider that I was sitting there, foodless for two hours after having informed them of  my hunger, while my friend ate. They did not consider that my friend then had to sit there, having completed his dinner, and watch ME eat. 

My food was cold and tasteless by the time it arrived. The salmon had a fishy taste not usually found in salmon. This meal was most certainly not worth the wait. 

In a city teeming with skilled servers, many of whom are probably un- or under-employed, it's incredible that La Traviata chose to hire Tweedle Dum and Tweedle Dee. The main idea of service at this restaurant appears to be 1. smile constantly and act as if your customers are delighted, even when it's obvious that they are not, 2. spend a lot of time conversing with customers, and 3. don't worry about the food, because probably your customers have eaten before they arrived.
author: Ange R.

description:
SO glad my house-sitter wanted dinner here as her "thank you" for tolerating my crazy travel schedule.  I was nervous at first, because at 6pm there was only one other table seated.  However, it was SRO by the time we left.  

The tables are set very carefully and the service is great.  I had the seafood pasta and we both loved the special fig salad.  For dessert, the profiteroles were swimming in the most delicious chocolate sauce.

I'm not a fan of the Mission, I am afraid, but I look forward to showing this place to more friends,
author: Joe R.

description:
So good and fresh. You won't be disappointed. Friendly and fancy in the mission, not usually found around these parts. A+ all the way. 

This place knows their recipes and is not your typical heavy bland Italian place.
author: Scottie L.

description: This has been my standby (very consistently good and a great value) restaurant for over 25 years. I never write reviews. I feel it is only right to give something back to them. You will not be disappointed! I have taken numerous friends to this spot- including friends who have lived in Rome- everything on the menu is delicious. Enjoy!
author: Carol J.

description: This place felt very homey and welcoming. It's as though you're dining at your Italian grandmother's home. The staff is unbelievably friendly, the food is tasty/of high quality.
author: Sarah D Z.

description:
I'm pleased to report that after a second night at La Traviata, I can retain a four-plus rating for it. 
The special this evening was a Sicilian-style lasagna with pine nuts and raisins.  It sounded delicious, and it delivered.  Could have been a little hotter, but I loved the lighter style sauce, and the use of beef and chicken, rather than the traditional beef and pork.
The vintages still haven't been updated on the menu, but this time it was to our advantage, in finding a 2007 Russian River Chardonnay, rather than the 2006 that was listed.  
Points for the parking, and kudos to the staff for yet another charming evening.
author: Theresa B.

description:
3.5 Stars

This is a place where you can apply the principle "Don't judge a book by its cover". La Traviata is situated on Mission between 24th-25th the last place you would expect  an authentic &; delightful Italian restaurant would be. 

The minute you walk in you are definitely taken to a different place, the word Mission Street wont even cross your mind.  As if you were in a little italian town.  The wall to wall decorations rather photos are definitely entertaining and makes you think the mob owns it :) :) :) 

* Would definitely comeback
*Good food & reasonable prices
*Wine selection is not so great but not bad either.
*Recommendation: Carbonara, Tortellini & The Bread

Ahhhhh...after a lovely evening filled with homey Italian food we exit its doors and bam reality hits you instantly!!! Back on 24th & Mish!
author: Christina D.

description:
Excellent, hot, soft bread
Great tomato and cream sauces
Very friendly and efficient service
author: Captain B.

description: Tucked away between taquerias this place has good Italian
author: Tiger H.

description:
Excellent, traditional, affordable,  hole-in-the-wall Italian...

La Traviata was a welcomed new Italian experience in SF. After years of dining in the Mission, I had somehow missed La Traviata until my cousin recommended the place. 

The food was excellent! I highly recommend the eggplant parmesan. The staff was gracious and fun. They helped celebrate a patron's birthday by turning down all the lights and playing a traditional Italian song and bringing out dessert.

Will definitely be going back.
author: malorie l.

description:
La Traviata
We had dinner at this culinary opera last evening---delightful.  When walking into La Traviata from Mission Street, one is immediately transported to a quaint Roman eatery.  The friendly and personable staff greeted us when we enter La Traviata.  It was like arriving at the home of the owner.  The service was OUTSTANDING beginning with drinks and the tasty HOT bread.  Our pasta and veal dishes were prepared perfectly.  The prices are very reasonable.  Even though I drove to the Mission District to eat at La Traviata, this terrific eatery is only half a block from the 24th Street BART Station.  Consequently, parking is not an issue.  The La Traviata experience is one that I have had before last evening and will certainly have again in the future.  EXCELLENT, LUSCIOUS, TERRIFIC!!!
author: John S.

description:
After living in the heart of the North End in Boston I will never look at Italian food the same way again.  

I grew up in an asian household. Our carb of choice was rice.  Until I left Jersey I thought Italian food was Chef Boyardee (which scared me because it smelled like socks and looked like bloodnguts).

The dr. and I walked in late on a Sunday night and the place was pleasantly lit, cozy and somewhat quiet with a handful of small parties left in the dining room which was covered in framed pictures of famous opera singers.

If this was Jersey, there would be red and white checkered vinyl tablecloths.

But it's the Mission.

Wait.  It's the Mission!

My head in all sorts of ethnic confusion I expected burritos and spaghetti.  

I was wrong.  The menu was your standard Italian fare.  I went for the gnocchi (red) since it has been awhile since I've had it and the dr. went for the fungus.

I'm with fellow yelpers, why is the bread burn-your-face-off hot?

I ate it anyway in honor of no carb left behind.  Everyone I know seems to be on the Atkins diet. I eat my white flours discreetly and try not to tell them I've been consuming more then 20g a day.

Food came and I refrained from scarfing it down.  It took some time to figure out what the interesting taste was in my gnocchi til in a moment of genius the dr. came up with nutmeg and the lightbulb came over my head too.  Ooooh, nutmeg.

You could tell the little dumplings were made from scratch which was awesome.

The lights went out in the dining room while they embarassed the birthday girl at one of the tables with an operatic version of the bday song.

The dr. and I lingered at our table for awhile awash in that glucose glow.  I like that when I reach across the table, he does too.

We walked out to a very sincere goodnight by the staff and I left feeling pretty warm and fuzzy despite not partaking of any wine.  

4 stars for the experience and the atmosphere.  Not so many stars for the food which is ok, but not even close to my old hood in Boston.
author: Jen I.

description:
La Traviata is a charming Italian restaurant in the Mission.  I've walked down Mission many times previously and never noticed the restaurant until I did a search of restaurants near my hood and this one popped up.  I'm so glad I ventured out and tried the place.  
The restaurant decor is interesting and nostalgic, making you feel like you're in a family owned Italian restaurant.  
The service is exceptional - friendly and attentive.
The food was fantastic.  From the baked to order bread that was served in the beginning of the meal, to the appetizer of stuffed portabella mushrooms (the sauce was so good I was lopping it up with the melt-in-your-mouth bread), to the main entree of salmon baked in parchment in a balsamic vinegar reduction - everything was exceptional and makes this a restaurant worth returning to.
author: michele g.

description:
warm and cozy.

they start you off with a sizeable amount of bread that comes out crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. and hot!

shared 5 dishes (family styled it):
pasta with seafood in cream sauce: soo yummy that im still thinking about it. there were tons of clams, shrimp and scallops.

layered eggplant: it was ok, seemed a bit overcooked.

veal parmigiana: always a great dish for me. really liked the sauce.

chicken wrapped around asparagus: super moist and flavorful. one friend recommended to eat it in small bites so it would last longer.

salmon baked in parchment: very tender! the waiter brings it out still wrapped in the parchment paper and slices open the paper and dishes it out.
author: Sabrina T.

description:
The man-friend surprised me (on my actual birthday) by taking me out to dinner at La Traviata. Awckward at first- we walk in and the restaurant is shaped like a horseshoe so' immediately everyone looks up at you when you walk in. We were greeted and seated with fresh HOT bread moments later. Yum. The dinner was insanely delicious and filling. We both unfortunately had no room for desert. 
NOTE: TO THOSE CELEBRATING YOUR BIRTHDAY- they dim all of the restaurant lights, play opera music while what sounds like count from sesame street, sings happy birthday. This just makes everyone laugh.

This place seems to be a local favorite. We must have seen at least a handful of people who knew the gentleman hosting and waiting everyone by first name basis. Excellent customer service.
author: Marel M.

description: I tried La Traviata for the first time and really liked it.  It is a cozy gem in the Mission District with just the right amount of background opera music.  I'ts a great restaurant if you want to enjoy a good meal along with interesting conversation and not have to compete with loud music.  The fresh bread served is outstanding.  They give generous servings of wine and the Pinot Grigio was very good.  Best of all was the meal itself.  I had the basa piccata with capers and it was delicious.  My partner's meal was also yummy.  The service was very good and the atmosphere is friendly.  I liked the overall ambiance with many pictures of patrons and celebrities on the walls.  A great Italian restaurant that is now on my list of favorites in San Francisco
author: Michelle I.

description:
Joined a friend for dinner last night at La Traviata. Enjoyed the Gargonzola Salad and chese ravioli with a nice glass of Pinot Grigio. It's definately one of the more affordable Italian restaurants in the city. 

The salad was fresh, the ravioli was good. But neither dish seemed all that more impressive than what I could make at home. 

The real reason to come here is to enjoy the service. The staff is super attentive and it's a great place to go if you just want to have a quiet dinner in an atmostphere that's great for long conversations.
author: Marissa P.

description: If you are looking for a quaint, cozy red-sauce Italian restaurant, this is the place! The food is delicious and unpretentious and the staff is warm and friendly. A wonderful break from the newer, glitzier offerings of the Mission.
author: Una A.

description:
Solid 4 rating. You get everything you are looking for in a great ambiance place without having to pay for it. Honestly, the prices here are pretty incredible for the service you receive. Traditional and flavorful. Really a great meal here every time.
So I have to admit, my "family" has been going here for nearly 30 years and are probably treated a TAD more biased than the average Joe. But the service is really great.....I DO pay attention to everyone around me when I dine out. 
If you haven't been here, you should try it out for sure. It's like stepping into another world here. I love places where you forget where and who you are... and don't have to pay for it later.
author: Jena D.

description:
What more can me said? I'm a bit reluctant to give a high rating, since I'd hate for this place to become popular. I want it to be my little secret.

I had out of town guests from Norway wanting to get Italian food. They wanted to get something at Fisherman's Wharf. My response to them was, tell me where you are, and I'll come pick you up and take you somewhere good. (i.e. not at Fisherman's Wharf)

Originally, I was going to go to Delfina, until I was told that it's a 4 week reservation wait for prime time spots. Screw that. My preference is always to go to places not packed. There's a myth that all the good places are packed. Certainly, lots of places are packed because they are good, but the packed places have no monopoly by any means.  There's plenty of diamond in the rough in this town, and La Traviata, being right by the 24th and Mission BART station on Mission no less, is certainly in the rough. After dining there, I can say, that it is certainly a diamond as well.

Well, my Norwegian friends called me back, sounding a bit frazzled. "There's lots of people riding on bikes, and everyone is crazy and shouting!"  Then I realized, that today is Critical Mass, and there was no way in hell I was going to drive anywhere. Fortunately, they never made it to Fisherman's Wharf and was at the Embarcadero. Quick hop on the BART, and quickly walking past some raucous homeless people,  they were there before you could say Luciano Pavarotti.

During and after the dinner, the consensus around the table was an enthusiastic thumbs up. Tortellini with white sauce, with red sauce, veal, chicken, spaghetti ai funghi, minestrone, carpaccio, Bruschetta, tiramisu, creme carmel, espresso, chianti classico. All superb!

My 10 year-old son accompanied me as well, and the waiter was very accommodating. He offered to add a side of angel hair pasta and marinara sauce on the side as insurance in case the veal was not up to the young man's standards. Smart man! The insurance wasn't needed, but was fully utilized. The plate was the first one empty.

The ambiance is cozy, wait staff is friendly and helpful. They are not as "polished" as the popular places, and sure they aren't the quickest, but, you don't go here for polish or to get a quick bite. You come here to sit, talk, laugh, enjoy the food, let the wine soak into your soul. When you are full is when you are full, when you leave is when you leave. My 10 year-old has not adopted my philosophy however, so he took the liberties of tracking down the waiter to hand him the card. Kids these days. Back in my day Italian food meant Chef-boyardee, and we liked it!

Great date place. Great friends place. Will come again definitely!
author: Boris C.

description: I've been coming here for 7 years now. I love this place we always get Veal La Traviata with the stuffed portabella and fried mozzarella. Dessert chocolate drizzled cream puffs. Need I say more.
author: Russell D.

description: Love this place - it's so bizarre to find a great Italian restaurant in the Mission, but I'm a big fan.
