We had the lasagne - perfect - and the salmon in parchment - a real stunner of a dish.  Food was perfectly cooked, served with expertise, and it's a great find.  Happy to be a repeat customer, and recommend it when a burrito in the nabe isn't quite what you are looking for.
author: R.B. W.

description:
I live right down the street from this place and had walked by it a million times without noticing. Then one day I was craving a good, hearty, Italian meal so I looked up Italian places near by and low and behold I saw there was one just a block away. My boyfriend and I went in and before we even sat down I was in love. The ambiance is so classic Italian with signed photos of opera singers plastering the walls, long white tablecloths, and a real freshly cut red rose on every table. 

On to the food: The pre-meal bread is warm, almost gooey, and delicious. You can tell that they bake it there. I ordered pesto gnocchi and my boyfriend ordered tortellini in white cream sauce. Both dishes were simple, traditional and delicious. The best part was sopping up all the yummy sauce with the homemade bread while you eat. I also liked that they bring out a HUGE bowl of Parmesan cheese when they serve you and they definitely don't skimp on it either.

This spot is perfect for a date, birthday celebration, or if you're just craving a no-fuss delicious Italian meal and really is a secret gem of the Mission!
author: Maya C.

description: My husband, son and I enjoyed a truly lovely meal here this past week.  An oasis of classic Italian charm in the bustling hipster/Mexican Mission District - opera theme. we sat in a booth and were treated well throughout our meal.  Our server was a gem: attentive, friendly and helpful.  The hot rolls ruled.  I had a veal dish that was out of this world - I can still taste the sauce - it was that memorable.  My son loved his tortellini (reasonably priced) in a not too heavy white sauce.  My husband was VERY happy with his seafood pasta.  Too full for dessert -though the portions were just right - We look forward to coming back.
author: Amy B.

description:
This was the second place my husband and I tried in SF on our visit and it was very much worth it.  I was yelping places in SF as I had no clue where to eat and the Hotel restaurant was not so appealing after trying there room service :(

The service was awesome as the wait staff was very attentive. My husband and I both had the Salmon in Parchment paper based in past reviews(thank you) and it was DELICIOUS!!!  The presentation was very cute as well. I really loved this dish.  Here's the run down:
Bruschetta (2 order) it was too good we had another
Salmon in Parchment paper x2 (husband and I both had) Great!!!!
A bottle of nice white wine suggested by the attentive staff. Great choice too.
NO dessert as we had our second order of brushcetta, I know but i loved it so.. :)

I cant remember the total but it was well worth it for the quality of food and service. I believe it was around 96 buck with tip.
That was great for us. 
We ended up going there 3 times on our stay :)
Got the Salmon dish second time and hubby got the sausage and mushroom pasta dish, bruschetta and I had the flan.
That was off the hook!!
Third time was I had the pasta dish with Shrimp and linguine, hubby had the same sausage pasta dish. This time they were closing and took us anyway. Great food to end out great trip! Salmon dish is a MUST HAVE!
author: V B.

description:
We're sipping Chianti.  Tony and Carmela are at the next table, and over by the entrance at a cozy candle-lit table for two,  Marty Scorcese and his Aunt Cathy are eating a pile of lasagna.

Not really, but you get the idea.

Complete with a waiter who has been slinging spaghetti at this place for 30-some-odd years, this place is all old-school Italian red sauce and ricotta cheese.  It's like all the hundred-year-old spots in NY's Little Italy have formed a stake-out in the Mission to keep an eye on things, and they took Nonna's recipe cards with them.

A scalding-hot hunk of bread is the starting point, and you can literally go anyplace from there:  But oh, my favorite lies in the little brolier-kissed dish of eggplant parmesean, maybe a little calamari salad and a few bites of their KILLER hommeade torellini in sinful alfredo sauce.

The warm-fuzzies start just after the first glass of wine, which is always inexpensive, though the temperature is always a few degrees north of where it should be... no matter.  Screw trekking out to North Beach!  This is all the authentic Italian you'll ever need this side of Canal Street.
author: Laura F.

description:
I'm giving this restaurant 3 stars just because I rarely give 4 stars.  However, I would come back again with a group hanging out.  

Wonderful for a party of 7 eating cheaply in the Mission.  We were a group looking for an inexpensive place to eat good food in the Mission and catch up in a comfortable environment.  First, we were happy to come in off the not-so-clean Mission street to a cozy Italian living room turned restaurant.  Loved the quick arrival of hot crispy bread per other reviews.  Appreciated how patient the waiter was with us while we yapped to each other and slowly ordered, and finally splitting the bill 7 ways with credit cards.  Heck, if I were the waiter, I'd be annoyed.

The food was good and homey.  I ordered linguine with clams and was pleasantly surprised by the large clams in my dish for only be $13.  My friend ordered the salmon, which smelled delicious, and my other friend ordered scallops, which were a bit strong on the sauce, but good overall.  Everyone was happy with the food and the chill environment to hang out.
author: Grace K.

description:
This place is like sweet, little, Italian titties!!!!  Not easy to come by in San Francisco, but once you find 'em MAN it's hard to stop thinkin' about them.  Seriously, not to be confused with nicely tanned California tits.  This place is THE tits.

A friend took me here last night, and I tossed and turned all night just thinking about the tortellini in cream sauce that accompanied my pollo piccata.  The restaurant is not in North Beach, no - it's in outer mission - not too far from the Foxy Lady Boutique (where your local hos likes to shop), across the street from La Taqueria (where your local hos like to dine), and a half block away from BART.  

Wow, this place took me back to little Italy in the Bronx, NY.  It is a hole in the wall, with pictures of old Opera singers covering every inch of wall space.  It is not like other Italian restaurants in San Francisco.  This place feels special.  They've been there for 35 years, so they've seen the neighborhood change, but you can tell they haven't changed much.  The food is soooo freekin good.  Melt in your mouth goodness, I tell you.  UH!  They serve until about 10pm on the weekdays.  Ruy was our server, and did a fabulous job, even gave us free flan at the end of our meal!!  So good. So good. Sooooo good.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Service? What service? Took forever to get our entrees and we even had to flag them over to come and get the check when we were trying to pay.

The food is average to good Italian. With average to good prices, but it's not cheap.

Maybe we just caught them on an off night (Saturday is an off night?), but the place was only 60% full, so I would have expected the service to be decent. Especially considering the reviews here claiming great service. Overall you can do much better. It was my first time going there, and I doubt I'll be back. Too many other good restaurants in the city.
author: Jim T.

description:
La Traviata is a great Italian restaurant. it seems off the beaten path. we got there late around 9ish. this stretch on Mission & 24th at this hour is dead. for a moment i thought maybe we were in the wrong block, as the restaurant has like a 10 foot wide front, with a small neon sign, which you can quite easily miss.

anyway, the interior looks like you are sitting in New York. the walls have pictures from back when this restaurant was a regular for opera giants as Pavarotti, Domingo, and Maria Callas (we are talking over 30 years now) the photographs are signed copies to the proprietors of this establishment. a couple of others which caught my eye was of a young Santana with his wife, and one of Keanu Reeves with his posse.

for starter they serve tortellini with white or mainara sauce and bread which is baked daily at the restaurant. it was fresh and so hot the butter literally melted into it.

we ordered three entree's. the first was ravioli on a bed of spinach which was a special -it was good. the second was sweet bread, cooked with tomatos, zucchini, onions and fresh herbs -pure delight. the last dish was salmon and recommended by the server, which i believe was baked in a filo dough. the puffy pastry was cut open at our table, and in there was the fish smothered in olives, diced tomato's, onions, and herbs -the flavors got marinated right into the fish. i loved it!

anyway, i will be back. the owner Jack is a cool dude. he let us stay later then usual. now i need to end, as im watching the Euro Cup, Germany vs. Portugal.
author: Sha A.

description:
3.5 stars, really. 3 stars for my food, but 4 stars for service. As he sat me and my girlfriends at a cozy booth, our waiter asked "Did you hear about the earthquake?" We were like "WHAT?!?" He said, "Well, 3 angels just felt out of the sky." Rather amusing, and a pleasant beginning to our evening. That's the strange thing about cheesy pickup lines. If they're directed at a group, they are funny and charming. But at one person, they are obnoxious.

La Traviata, as many other reviewers have pointed out, is smack dab in the heart of the Mission. It's a rather unexpected locale, especially when you walk into the richly decorated foyer. The dining room is adorned with photos of opera divas, past and present.

First, they serve hot bread. I mean HOT BREAD. The butter melts right into it. It's hard not to just scarf it all down. I maintained my discipline so I could eat the actual meal. I started with the Caesar salad, which I'm afraid to say was somewhat disappointing. The lettuce was crisp and fresh, but the dressing was anchovy overkill. I love me some anchovy-y Caesar dressing, but this was ridiculous. It was like anchovies pureed and poured over romaine. Not really my cup of tea. I couldn't even finish half of it. For my main course, I had the tortellini soup. It contained about 20 or so pieces of tortellini in a light chicken brodo. It was decent. Not bad, but not super memorable.

Although I felt lukewarm about my food, my fellow diners seemed to enjoy their dishes very much, and due to the friendly service and cute vibe of the place, I round my rating up to 4 stars.
author: Jill M.

description: From New York. 30 years looking for a good Italian family-style restaurant in SF. Disappointment after disappointment.  The came La Traviata. Superb food. Great atmosphere and staff. Veal scallopini the way it's supposed to be (no knife needed),; outstanding lasagna and soup.  Great desserts.  Just wonderful homemade food. Go there.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Archie G.

description: Great, unpretentious, and very cute service - loved the family cooking & family service.  The best part though was the food - starter bread was warm and yummy, salad w figs was unique and delicious, chicken tosca was a delight - perfection! Wine was also well priced and good quality & dessert (Creme caramel) was to die for - definitely our new favorite Italian in SF.
author: Lilian R.

description: Uh, no thank you, sir. We came here for new years with a large group. We were told that their menu was limited that night because they ran out of other dishes. Our choices were: chicken breast, veal and salmon with a caper sauce. Period. Compared to the large menu they advertise on their website, this was a bit disconcerting. And our reservation was 7pm, so I also found it very odd that they ran out of all of the other dishes by that point in the evening. As I dislike white meat and am morally opposed to veal, I ordered the salmon (despite my dislike of capers). The food was edible (my bf had the veal and said it wasn't anything special), but definitely nowhere near 4 stars. The place was altogether too warm and I thought that given the quality of food and ambiance, it was way overpriced. I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Nora G.

description:
Service: 4 stars
Food: 3 stars

La Traviata is one of two inexpensive Italian restaurants in the mission (Beretta being the other). I've been here a few times and am happy to recommend it to friends.

The pasta and risotto dishes are tasty and properly cooked and have generous portion sizes. They are good, but not exceptional.

The service here is excellent and suits a much fancier restaurant. The staff are attentive, knowledgeable and friendly, and stop by regularly to refill glasses, bring more bread and ensure everything is okay.
author: Paul S.

description: I'm italian and this restaurant is italian only in the name. Food is mediocre at best.
author: Valentino V.

description:
Rule No. 1: Don't go into any establishment with YIE (Yelp Inflated Expectations). 

Rule No. 2: Don't forget Rule No. 1.

So this place is decent, but not that good. The average yelp rating of 4 stars, where n = more than 50, is definitely wrong. Yelp users are generally so picky that anything with overall 4 stars could easily be comprised of lots of individual 5-star ratings. One of which is often me. But this is not the case at La Traviata. 

The decor is reminiscent of a Sopranos Sunday family dinner, and the photos cool, but the over-the-top opera music is tacky.

And the food was mostly mediocre (not Olive Garden crap mediocre, but not much I'd recommend). I liked the chicken al forno, which you preorder 30 minutes ahead and comes with a side of tortellini. The rest of my party (which got the garlic-basil pasta, the mushroom pasta, and the eggplant parmesan) had very average meals. 

Delfina is better. Even places in Palo Alto (Osteria, Cafe Pro Bono) are much better. Not terrible, but don't make a special trip.
author: Gloria L.

description:
It's been 6 months since I've been here.  Normally, with my memory being as hazy as it is (I filled it up with baseball player statistics at age 5.  No room left since), I'd find it hard to write a fair review.  But the food at La Traviata was so unremarkable there was nothing to forget!  Thank you, I'll be here all night.

Seriously though.

We went on a weeknight, and it was totally dead.  I could see this place being more fun with wine glasses tipping back and a big crowd of people indiscriminately devouring this comfort-style Italian food. The photos on the wall, friendly waitstaff, and "what the hell?" across-from-La-Tacqueria location would probably make for a happy atmosphere if there were more than one other table in the place.  But I'm more "that tall villainous critic from Ratatouille" than what you might call "fun". Pungent, fresh ingredients, inventive dishes, and unusual delicacies.  That's what I want in an Italian restaurant.  

But to find Italian gourmet in the heart of the Mexican part of the Mission?  Too good to be true, right?  Why, yes, yes it is.
author: Jack S.

description:
Walking down Mission street you would never think there could be high quality authentic Italian food in the mist of an almost infinite supply of burritos and cheap Chinese food. 

La Traviata is like a mirage in the mission. You walk inside and it's cute, dark and clean. How would have ever suspected this place, I certainly didn't. Here's to roommates that found it!

The bread was super solid, hot and fresh, the pasta was excellent high marks all around. The wine was amazing too... If you're in the mission and looking for Italian, this is your place. 

I didn't checkout the bathrooms, sadly, so I'll have to update this review when I do.
author: Michael S.

description:
An Italian-American restaurant firmly stuck in 1950's American kitsch. It's fun, definitely has character,  with a charming staff, an over-the-top cheesy-romantic atmosphere. Opera memorabilia covers the walls, and Pavarotti sings treacly popera over the speaker system. According to our waiter's apocryphal account, in its heyday, La Traviata used to shut down to feed the cast of the SF Opera before big performances. The cast might have long since departed decades ago, but La Traviata has pretty much remained the same.

The one area in which it lacks is in its food -  non-offensive and ordinary, there really isn't much to get excited about.

But if you're willing to overlook that niggling detail in deference to a flight of kitschy nostalgia (and affordable prices), this would be the place. I personally wouldn't choose to come here again, but I can see how plenty of other people would.
author: Umami Y.

description: This is my favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  I've been several times with my coworkers and they quickly accommodated 20 of us.  The food is delicious and fresh.  Don't expect to get in and get out though, they do take their time but thats all a part of the experience.
author: Victoria L.

description: I love this restaurant. No frills Italian food at good prices (the horrible, horrible pasta at Pizza Joint down the street has comparable prices). Friendly and unique. For Italian in the Mission, it doesn't get better than this place.
author: Maggie C.

description:
3.5 stars.

came here with a group of 10 and had a pleasant meal here.  i never think of tradiitonal italian when i go to the mission but was surprised by this place.  ambience is really old school italian haunt and great place for groups.  apparently, it's a great place for birthdays because every other table in the restaurant besides us was celebrating (we knew this because a loud italian birthday song would blare from the speakers each time).

prices are very reasonable for the portions and this is a good choice if you're looking for no frills italian in the mission.
author: Helen T.

description:
Walking down Mission, you'd never expect to push open a door to find a cozy, dark-wood paneled Italian restaurant very nearly wallpapered in photos and art.  In a way, it feels a bit like you've walked into someone's dining room.
The service is friendly almost to the point of absurdity.  The winelist is reasonable, and the food is good.  Amazing?  No... but certainly good.
Further, you get free tortellini with any of the meat dishes. If that isn't enough to convince you, there's almost never a wait - somehow La Traviata has continued to remain a secret.
Now that you know, take advantage of it!
author: Don H.

description:
made from scratch and fresh! everything. from the warm loaves of bread before your meal (which they also use for the bruschetta) to the gnocchi. 

our server was awesome and offered great advise from the food and wine menu.

this is not your typical boring pasta place.
author: danielle m.

description:
Ready S and I enjoyed an amazing meal at La traviata a couple weeks back.  Brought up italian and having lived in NYC for years before heading West I truly felt that SF could not deliver the old school, home cooked, delicious italian food I knew and loved.  I WAS WRONG.

La Traviata is excellent. Amazing, pleasureable, enjoyable - i could go on and on.  If you like straight up no joke italian food get over there immediately.
author: Jenn R.

description:
I debated giving it 1 star and a really bad review just so it wouldn't blow up.  I love this place.  I want it to make money and I want people to enjoy the food... but I hope I never ever have to wait in line.  Selfish?  Of course.   But where else can you find quality Italian food in the Mission?  Everything about it reminds me of a restaurant I used to frequent on Mulberry St. in Little Italy.  Cheesy, of course, but that's what makes it homey.  Study up on your Best of Opera compilations and you can sing along while you wait for the insanely hot but super delicious bread to cool off.

But please, don't bring all your friends here.  I like it too much.
author: Jess H.

description:
I always hesitate to review places that are well-covered, but since I went here based on Yelp reviews, thought I might as well.

Very cozy atmosphere--it looks more expensive than it actually is, which is a nice surprise! I love the opera music playing, too. It's comfort food--good, solid Italian, of a style you don't find very often anymore. A very old-fashioned place with wonderful service. I didn't love it quite enough to want to go back soon, but it's nice to have in my back pocket.
author: Arwen O.

description:
Reminiscent of Boun Gusto's in South City, yet with a more city feel to it.  The service is perfect, they bake their own bread, the wine is supurb and the food even better!  I love the ambiance and the fact that it's quite affordable.  This tried and true restaurant can't be recommended highly enough!

Next time I fully expect to see a Tony Soprano-type be ushered behind some black curtain somewhere.  This place beats anything in North Beach by far.
author: Tracy B.

description:
If you are in the mood for good Italian food, this is a great place to go in the Mission.  The food is very good, you can't beat hot freshly baked bread right to your table.  I would give it 3.5 stars.  Very good vegetarian options, the pasta's are all delicious, and the eggplant parmigiana is amazing.

I only give it 3.5 stars because the service is not great and very hit or miss.  We have been there a few times and the people are nice, but just don't seem very organized.
author: Rajeev R.

description: Ya think this would be a hole-in-the-wall place and is somewhat like that in this part of the Mission District. It looks somewhat fancy when you step inside though. A guy who worked there (seems like he was the owner... maybe...) was nice enough to talk with us for a couple of minutes. I ordered a Beverly Sills (stuffed chicken with cheese and what seems to be beef or something). It was alright. Nothing to write home about though.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I went here solely for one reason: lasagna.  Luckily for me, it was the special of the night (not normally on the menu).  I'm a very picky lasagna lover, but I'd give La Traviata's lasagna 4 out of 5 stars..  One star for it being a special, one star for the perfectly sized portion (I was full afterwards), one star for not putting too much ricotta in it, and one star for the entire dished being cooked to perfection (not too baked, not too soggy).  I'm taking one star away for too much meat, though :(

I'd come here again :)  Very intimate setting and pretty quiet.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Hidden gem! Been in business for about 34 years, still in the family. John has been running the place for 13 years and it's still serving delicous home cooking! Italian and heart felt! You can really feel the passion and their love for food. 

Their special app baked Portabella Mushroom with melted provalone and prawns was amazing! Flavor in every bite. 

They have a delicous white sauce that is absolutely to die for! 

Service is friendly, walk-ins accepted, but if you have a huge party it's always nice to call ahead. John would appreciate that~ 

Espresso machine is down due to the power outage they experienced on Friday 1/04/08. 

Worth every cent, they are so reasonably priced!
author: Judi K.

description:
I am picky about service having been a server myself for a very long time and this place excels. Wonderful, attentive, friendly service. Without asking, we were brought a side of pasta for my little girl and a dessert menu. The latter is kind of a pet peeve of mine--I hate being brought the check before I have been offered dessert--so the fact that they brought me a menu without me even asking speaks to a level of service much higher than most similarly-priced places in town. 

The food was great, old-school Italian. I had clam linguine, my husband had the carbonara and both were excellent. Be sure and try the grilled eggplant appetizer, totally delicious. Lots of wines for under $40 a bottle ( we had a perfectly decent Sangiovese for about $30). Menu prices are very reasonable too.

Highly recommend for a nice family dinner. We will be back!
author: Christy B.

description: The food was good and the atmosphere was homely. I thought there could've been better lighting though. It was a bit too dark for my tastes.
author: Arish A.

description:
I had a hankering for good Italian last night so my boyfriend and I decided to come here.  

The waiter was very friendly, the bread was hot, the music and decor were fabulous, and the food was delicious: I had the Salmone Alla Wixell and he had the Chicken Alla Beverly Sills. 

I felt kind of bad for the waiter since it seemed he was the only one there for a while (until another guy came out to help).  When he did come to our table though, he was helpful, polite, and funny, and you wouldn't have guessed that he had a million other things to do as well.  Needless to say, we left him a pretty good tip.
author: Rick B.

description: Yet another place where authentic Italian food is served rightly in terms of service, taste, price. The waiters are friendly and cater to special needs like if younare running late. Excellent taste and a nice treatment to the customers.
author: Pawankumar H.

description:
I'm giving La Traviata a big five stars because it's just bloody irreplaceable. For starters: A family-owned and -run, old-school-liek-whoa Italian restaurant located in the guts of Mission Street? What are the chances? For secundi: It's a dark, plush time warp of a place, all mellifluous opera soundtrack and big red booths and dark wooden walls covered with autographed portraits of divas past and present (mostly past). 

Naw, the food isn't trendy, but it's sincere and fulsome. Mmmm... squid and pasta. The bread is baked fresh, and the staff recognizes you by your second visit. Plus, if you celebrate your birthday there, they dim the lights, put on Pavarotti and bring out a slice of candelit tiramisu. Dude. If that's not some new circle of heaven, I don't know what is.
author: girl x.

description:
This place is ADORABLE!  We walked in and it definitely felt like you stepped into another place.  All the photos on the wall made the place a little Buca de Beppo-esque, without the crazy screaming atmosphere.

There was only one waiter (poor guy) to serve all the tables, so it was a little slow.  The bread was fresh out of the oven, our entrees come with a side of tortellini (with your choice of cream or tomato sauce).  The mozzerella appetizer is to die for; I just wish I could say the same about the entree (or maybe I was so stuffed from everything else I couldn't appreciate it to its fullest).

They even dim the lights and blast the "Happy Birthday" song over their speakers!  Way to feel special.
author: Jenny L.

description:
When my friend told me we were going to an Italian place in the Mission, I thought she was kidding.  Or misinformed.  Nope, wrong again.  La Travista is a really cute restaurant with a kitschy feel and a neat looking hatched ceiling nestled in between various taquerias and markets.  Random, but what hell.

The bread was prolly the best part of the meal.  It was warm and yummy and me, along with my party, couldn't get enough.  My entree wasn't as good as the bread, unfortunately.  I had the Carbonara pasta, and I think it was the sauce that threw it all off for me.  It lacked flavor and punch, I was disappointed.  I heard the tortillini was amazing though.

The service was pretty good, everyone else seemed to really enjoy their food, except me, so I give this place a 3.5 starts.  Next time I go back I'll most likely get the tortillini and bump this place up to a solid 4 star.
author: Erika C.

description:
This little Italian restaurant is one of my favorite hidden spots in San Francisco. The atmosphere is hushed, making it the perfect location for a romantic dinner or a phenomenal place to take the folks when they're visiting from out of town.

This is probably one of the best kept secrets of San Francisco dining. The food is phenomenal and well-priced and, because the place is such a secret, there's very rarely a full crowd. The staff is congenial and the restaurant has a really interesting history to it. 

My favorite dish at La Traviata is the fried mozzarella. I hate to choose such a mundane dish, something that's standard fare at almost any Italian restaurant, but it's true - this is the BEST fried mozzarella I've ever had. The marinara sauce is exceptional and they use truly fresh cheese to make the dish. 

I recently hosted a party at La Traviata with 10 people who hadn't ever been there. After the dinner, every person was blown away by the food and the experience - they just couldn't believe they'd never heard of this place!

Part of me wants to keep La Traviata the secret that it is, but I'd rather have to deal with a long reservation list and see this place thrive than risk it continue to be the overlooked flower that it is. 

Enjoy!
author: Hannah Q.

description:
Wow, incredible tasty Italian, and a classy joint run by such friendly folks!  Me, my Sis, and her boyfriend went here just on a whim passing by on Halloween night.  They were costumed up, and when we walked in we were afraid it might be a little to fancy for our silly costumes, heh.  But the gentleman was super nice and they were more then happy to have us and take good care of us all night.  Service and drinks were all spot on, no problems.  Apparently lots of famous people have eaten there.  Pics included Keanu Reaves and the Carlos Santa family.  There was even an older pic of the owner (I think) with HW Bush, lol.

My friend and I had the Alla Carreras, homemade spaghetti with tons of italian sausage, mushrooms, and a moderate amount of rich tomato sauce.  It was amazing, and super filling.  Was already full by 3/4 done, but we both finished anyway because it tasted so good.  My Sis had the Pollo Ai Ferri, marinated chicken breast stuffed with asparagus and oregano.  She loved it!

Pricing is actually less then I thought for as nice a restaurant as this was.  Entrees were only around $15 each, very reasonable.  Only the veal selections (which I do NOT do ever) got over $20 each.  Drinks were normal pricing for a decent restaurant.  Big wine selection, and they will help you decide if needed.  Definitely worth checking out!  Would be great for a date too.  I'll go back next time I'm in town and want Italian!
author: Pepper S.

description:
3.5 stars

Cute place, opera playing in the background, opera pictures in eclectic frames covering the walls - an atmosphere that takes into another world for the time it takes to eat your meal.  The food is not new fangled or fad-affected; it is traditional and old world feeling.  That is not to imply that you will recognize everything on the menu; there's still some room for exploration here - pasta with squid ink sauce for example.  The place feels a bit like a mafia family could run it or else a mafia family could walk in and demand a meal (maybe this is my imagination running now).  Anyway, the food is good and unpretentious, but still nice in a date night kind of way.  Bring a friend, a date, or a group of hungry people, and I think you'll find yourselves happy and full at the end of your meal!
author: Amy C.

description: Went to la traviata on my birthday and had a great experience. Had the tortellini with cream sauce and it was spectacular. Great atmosphere with music and fun pictures on the wall of opera greats. To top it all off, I got a free tiramisu for my birthday. This may have been better than the main course. They also brought down the house lights and had happy birthday play over the speakers. This was quite embarrassing. Highly, highly recommend la traviata.
author: Kevin B.

description:
My man and I ate here for the first time last night, and weren't one bit disappointed. Overall, the place is nice, in a fake rose on the table sort of way. The friendly and attentive wait staff with Italian accents were a comforting hint at the authentic food we were about to be treated to.

Our meal began with a basket of warm, crusty bread, which I suspect they baked themselves. And the accompanying plate of mellon-balled butter was a nice touch. We both ordered a glass of Sangiovese (which went perfectly with our meal) and split a caesar salad. If you like anchovies, you'll love their caesar---the dressing had lots of 'em.

We ordered the eggplant parmigiana...sliced super thin, layered, and cooked perfectly in a delicious red sauce. Even better was the "Tinta": linguine topped with (also perfectly cooked) calamari pieces and drenched in the most delicious tomato, olive oil, garlic, and squid ink sauce I've ever eaten. The ink gives the sauce a brownish color (like chipotle salsa), and though our waiter claims to have never eaten the dish because of its color, I think we convinced him he was really missing out. It was so yummy, I'm already craving it.

La Traviata is a real Italian-American escape from a neighborhood over-saturated by hipster hangouts and taco joints. Try it! But leave your taste for slick at the door---this place is about the food. Real Italian style.
author: Shannon R.

description:
How can you not like a place that plays Italian Opera, has fantastic food, and the waitstaff/owners are very polite, not over attentive - really feels like a restaurant in Italy.. 

The bread is some of the best in the city, and the Bruchetta is always super tasty and fresh..
author: teague k.

description: A very nice  and romantic restaurant that makes you forget you're in the Mission!! The food was delicious. Carbonara Pasta and the Chicken Picatta, was superb. The tortellini that came with my entree (  white sauce)  was sooo good, we dipped our bread to finish the sauce. The service  was slow, so make it a place where you enjoy and chat for a while. The bread was hot and yummy. The older waiter was  charming, he's been there for 37 years and is 74 years old!!
author: B C.

description:
I've been living in the City about 17 years now and this is one restaurant I go to over and over again. It's the best Italian food I've found in the City and the service is really friendly to boot. It's great for a date, or just a great night out with friends.

The wine list is nice and extensive, but not outrageously priced. Warm fresh bread arrives at your table minutes after you sit down. We always get the same thing since it's so damn good and we're afraid to try something new: friend mozzarella, tortellini, and the Chicken alla Beverly Sills. 

The ambiance is great....especially if you are an opera lover with it's signed portraits of singers that have graced the San Francisco Opera stage. The waiter says a lot of the orchestra members of the Opera and Symphony are regulars.

Hope this place never goes out of business. We drive over from Alameda now and it's worth it!
author: Steven C.

description:
A great place for dinner AND conversation.  You don't need to compete with the next table for air time. Very warm and friendly service. The salad special with mission figs in a balsamic vinegar and sherry reduction was excellent. I was debating between a pasta or meat entree, selected the "La Traviata" (veal, prosciutto and cheese) and was pleasantly surprised that as a side, I had a choice of cheese tortellini w/ red or cream sauce (chose the red).  Great bread, too!

The waiter didn't write down our orders and ordered the wrong veal dish for me, but did bring my dish very quickly. 

And did I mention the salad was excellent?
author: Theda E.

description:
La Traviata is reminiscent of places you would find tucked away somewhere in the NY Tri-State area. Or maybe it's the outside world of Mission street that makes one feel as if they fell down the rabbit hole and landed in some other world (away from SF).

Friendly service, good food, and an efficient wine list (that will leave you buzzed yet again in the Mission). Like Lucca's, Molinari's, and Il Borgo, try it at least once.
author: Be N.

description:
Pretty solid.  Got good rich food.  Not too expensive, but not too cheap.  The food was served very quickly for us which was great because we were in a rush.  There were 3 birthdays that night... and they handle birthdays pretty well at this place.

I was happy even though I really just wanted a burrito..
author: Marcus E.

description:
I woke up the morning after eating at La Traviata still talking about our wonderful experience!  

We made a reservation, but our table wasn't ready due to a couple that stayed and talked for 20 minutes after they paid their bill. The management didn't want to rush them out (which I think was an appropriate choice) so they brought us each a glass of cabernet and we made ourselves cozy in the waiting area. They were very apologetic about the whole situation.

We brought an out of town friend here. She's the go-getter type who isn't afraid to ask for something even if it isn't on the menu.  She asked if they could make a beef ragu for us, even though it wasn't listed.(They agreed because all three of us wanted to order the same thing) My husband and friend had it over gnocci, I had it over spaghetti. Let me tell you... they really really need to add it to the menu because it was OUT OF THIS WORLD.

Tender pieces of carrot and celery mingled with the spice and tang of the tomatoes and beef. simply amazing. all three of us cleaned our plates.

The tiramisu for dessert was light and delicious. A perfect ending to a perfect meal. We'll definitely be back, (and we'll be sure to call ahead to make sure John is working so that we can get that fabulous ragu again!!)

meraviglioso!
author: Melissa J.

description:
Italian is in short supply in The Mission, so needless to say my expectations werent too high. Im glad to say that I was pleasantly surprised! Not only was the atmosphere great, the food was very good, and the price is unbeatable. 

Dont forget to order an extra bottle of wine with all the dough youre saving on the food.

I plan on making this place a regular spot.
author: Jeshua B.

description: Looks crummy on the outside, but actually really charming (and kind of romantic) on the inside. This place is great.
author: DE B.

description:
the food, atmosphere, and service are wonderful at la traviata.  the staff is incredibly friendly and the restaurant is cozy.  the walls are covered in photos that are fun to look at (recognize anyone?).  

i've been to la traviata several times and have always been pleased.
author: Anjanette M.

description: Enter the time warp, and enjoy 1950s Italian-AMERICAN style food. Walls covered with kitchy Italian photos and it's not a manufactured put-on like Bucca de Beppo's.  The food is made with heart, and pride: warm fresh baked bread, and a garlicky shrimp pasta dish make for a wonderful meal.  The place is deceptively small, since one wall is mirrors, the restaurant seems to stretch until you realize you're looking at yourself. Vaulted curved ceiling...like being in a wine cellar.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
You would be hard pressed to find a decent italian restaurant in the Mission if not were it for this restaurant.  The interior with it's unique lighting, sound system, opera oriented photos really make this place as charming as any mom and pop restaurant you will find in North Beach.

Price is affordable and the pasta was delicious.  It is your basic fare.  Not a Delfina but homey and comfortable.
author: Laurence H.

description:
The best eggplant parmigiana I have ever had!

Oh, I forgot to tell you that I am italian, which means that I have been eating ridiculously good, authentic italian food my entire life.

Vibe was chill, of course, it's in the mission.

Oh, and stay away from the puttanesca if you know anything about puttanesca.  They made it with black olives and no garlic!  Please?!?

Over all, I would definitely go back here again ... if nothing more than to have the eggplant!  YUMMY!
author: Montana D.

description:
I'm not sure where this quote came from, but I've heard it from a bunch of people of my parents' generation who grew up on the east coast: "when i was growing up, there were three kinds of restaurants: Chinese, Italian, and Fancy"

This is that kind of old-school Italian restaurant. Veal parm was pretty good. Atmosphere was over-the-top Sopranos style: dark, quiet, pictures of Frankie Avalon. Totally out of place on Mission Street.

I'll be back.
author: Josh K.

description: We should have just split a meal, but it was GREAT!!!!!  The service was amazing, the bread perfect!!!!  Large portions for the price and amazing ambiance.   Go Go Go if you like quality Italian food.
author: Rikki S.

description: Went here on a friends recommendation to meet some friends who bailed last minute on a Friday.  Ended up deciding to dine alone the place was totally empty, had the best tortellini I have ever had.  I usually don't go much for Italian since it's one of those you can make it at home dishes.  I can't wait to find an excuse to come here again.  They were very friendly as well.  I love that the walls were covered in photos was something to look at while dining without feeling bored.
author: Nirea S.

description:
Very busy on the Wednesday night that we were there. They appeared to be short staffed and the waiter took forever to take our order. He did however make up for it afterwards with the icecream desert.

Food was top notch.
author: Melissa R.

description:
I've been here several times, and have never been dissatisfied.  Last Saturday, however, I ordered the special "Italian Pastitsio" and it was quite  possibly one of the best meals of my life.  

If I could give La Traviata six stars for having amazing food and also delicious hot bread every time I walk in there, I would, but Yelp has to have rules, you know.
author: Claire T.

description:
I'm glad to see this place getting some love here although I enjoyed thinking it was my secret place. I enjoy the atmosphere, the service and the food each time I go.

It's been in operation in that location since way back when that area was an Irish neighborhood, and my extended family (three generations) have been going there for family gatherings since the 50's.
author: Dav Y.

description:
Excellent food. Very simple and authentic. It was rainy and gross outside but you come inside and feel like you are a million miles away from the rain and mayhem on mission.
The antipasta misto had good meat and cheeses. The Caprese wasn't anything special but was fine. The Carbonara and Eggplant Parmigiana were both very tasty. Simple but quality food. Yelp has their hours wrong so ignore that. The owner and wait staff are very attentive. YUMMY!
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Basically eating at La Traviata is like taking a step into an authentic Italian restaurant that has been in SF for over 50years. The ambiance is great and the service is usually good especially if the Italian owner is helping out.  His charm and courtesy can make the experience better than the food.

 Sadly the best thing on the menu is not on the menu and that is the free bread. The Bread warm and comes straight out of the oven to your table. MMMM. The pastas are good but nothing to write home about. As for the entrees Ive had a couple of them and would say its mediocre at best. The Wine list is good for such a small place.
author: Joseph M.

description: Located in the heart of the Mission, is this great little Mom & Pop restaurant.  Chose this place because of the positive comments on Yelp (Thank you Yelpers!).  My husband and I decided to celebrate our 9 year wedding anniversary here and so glad we did!  We started with the Calamari in Vinaigrette, the calamari was nice and far from being rubbery.  The meal also comes with delicious fresh bread, when they bring it to your table steam is coming from the basket!  My husband had the special of the evening which was a nice portion of lasagna and I had the seafood pasta in cream sauce which had clams, scallops, shrimps and mussels.  For the first 5 minutes there was no talking between us,  we kept nodding at each other and exchanging glances of "Holy Bajeeezus this is delicious!".  We ate ourselves into a carb coma (darn that delicious fresh bread!!!!) so we didn't have a chance to have any dessert.  Service was great.  There were only 2 people working the dining area, they served about 7 tables with parties between 2-7 and they did a great job keeping all of us happy!  Loved the ambience, dim lighting, light opera playing in the background and pictures on all walls of opera singers , family & friends.  Great place for a dinner date, birthdays  or just catching up! Will definitely be coming back!
author: Bernie R.

description: Going to La Traviata was a good enough excuse to miss Gossip Girl. This place hasn't changed their interior decor since it opened, and that just makes it all the more charming. We started out with the Caprese Salad, then the mozarella in carozza, the pasta ai funghi and finished with the panacotta. Words cannot describe how amazing the food is. Soooo good. and the home baked bread is yummi too.
author: Michelle K.

description:
We have been coming to La Trav for special family occasions for the past 13 years. We love the staff and the Tortellini in cream sauce is a MUST. It melts in your mouth!

Now we have small children, so when we take them we try to visit early in the dinner hour because the atmosphere is subdued and the room is intimate.

The owner (John) is a really nice guy, and we love this place!
author: Tonya S.

description:
The food here was disgusting.  

I should end the review there.  For me, all the ambiance and service in the world cannot save bad food.  The ambiance here is good-- cozy and vibrant on a Saturday evening.  Great.  Get that nice warm bread.  Nice.  The bread was good.  Prices are relatively cheap.  I'm feeling good about the meal.  I ordered what was basically chicken with fettucine and cream sauce.  Here's where things took a wrong turn.  The chicken was super processed.  It really didn't taste like chicken.  The pasta was hard and stale.  The sauce was oily and flavorless.  Disgusting.

Maybe it was just my dish.  That's possible.  But why would you take the chance?  There are so many great Italian restaurants in the city.  I would recommend any of them over this one.
author: Vishal K.

description: The thing I liked about this place was the bread, which we had to ask for. The Shrimp pasta I had was unremarkable at best. That hot fresh bread though... Mmm
author: Leo V.

description: Total Sopranos episode kinda place with amazing bread.  I always go w/ the frutti di mare here as it never disappoints.
author: Kim K.

description:
Eddies of wind were tossing flotsam about down the corridor of Mission Street. The occasional papered-over store front, the catcalls,  the overhanging utility wires, the scavengers rummaging around for spare cans and bottles, well this block could be anywhere in America. As I pick up the sounds of a distant mariachi band, I'm reminded that I'm in the Mission and passing the infamous La Taqueria. 

Instead, I veer into an oft passed-by doorway that leads to a waiting room that envelopes me in a Jersey Grandma aesthetic. Old school furniture, fake ivy plants, and pink and burgundy accents funnel me toward the dining room where my companion awaits my arrival and faint opera music cancels out any memory of the brassy mariachi band. La Traviata is deeply steeped in the old school style and serves comforting, cheese heavy, American Italian dishes that match the decor.

One can find a decent meal on the menu by sticking to breaded meats (chicken, veal ($16.95), etc) or eggplant blanketed in melted mozzarella and some of the house pastas (~$10-12). Gnocchi ($11.95) were less successful and down right mushy. Not totally unpleasant, but not the feathery light dumplings touted by the modern Cal-Ital kitchens about town. Rosy pink garlic, cream, and tomato aurora sauce did what it could to save the large dumplings, but couldn't hide their overcooked state.

The wine list is concise and provides easy drinking varietals that go down easy. Thick, stubby, balloon style stemware adds to the feeling that you're at your Jersey aunt/Grandma's house. Service is friendly and checks back often enough to see how things are going.  An easy neighborhood spot for when you don't feel like dealing with loud crowds, 2.5 and 3 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: This is definitely the best Italian restaurant I've eaten at.
author: Jason B.

description: Great Italian food in a fun old world environment. I liked the menu selection, my meal was tasty. It is in a fun area of SF that has burgeoning night life. I would go again
author: Stephen C.

description:
I'm totally into it.  This place is small.  The food is REALLY good, in an unassuming "kinda-like-mom used to make.... but better" way.

We split a special and had some great pasta.  All fresh and delightful.  $40 each with a bottle of wine.

Be careful the bread is good but REAL hot.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I'm pretty picky about Italian food at restaurants, and I think it's because I can actually COOK really freaking fabulous Italian food on my own at home (if I may say so, myself). And believe me, it is the one and only domain I have mastered, in terms of culinary expertise. 

So whenever I go out to eat at an Italian restaurant, I'm always kind of sending out this silent message to the cooks, like, impress me...make me something that I can't make...and at La Traviata, that didn't exactly happen. Never the less, I still enjoyed the dinner, and the old world Italian-American decor is definitely charming. I don't think I'll be coming here too often, especially considering that we threw down about 40 bucks for two, but it was a nice restaurant to at least add to my repertoire. I DO think I would go to Joe's of Westlake in Daly City for down-home Italian over La Traviata (I think the two are quite comparable), but then again, I can walk to La Traviata. so in the end, it's a toss up.
author: Shannon R.

description:
The food was pretty good, and the waiters were nice.  But we had a bit of a misunderstanding about the main courses.  My friend ordered one of the veal dishes which came with a side of tortellini.  He chose the cream sauce.  I ordered the tortellini as a main (also with cream sauce).  So the server comes out with a small portion of tortellini, which I mistakenly assume is mine.  And out of courtesy, I don't start in on it until my two friends have food.  So we ended up sitting there with the tortellini untouched in front of me for maybe 5 min.  It got to the point where we had to ask for the rest of our food. 

Turns out that they do the side as a dish between the appetizer and the main.  So the (now cold) tortellini sitting in front of me was my friend's side dish.  I guess they were too busy to tell us what was going on. But when we asked for our food, it came right out.
author: Hilary K.

description: Great food and good deserts. You have to go this place!!!!!!! My new favorite place.
author: A M.

description:
We were recommended La Traviata for a family dinner in a restaurant NOT on the tourist beat in San Francisco.
La Traviata is a real find. Be assured though its location is among decidedly mixed storefronts in this historic Mission district it is a gem within. Tables with fresh flowers and the true famiglia setting. A warm welcome and acknowledgement of our reservation at the door and an accomplished server explained various entrees on their extensive menu.
We enjoyed California prosecco wine and a truly lovely dinner, the highlight was when the older gentleman who had seated us came to our table to add piping hot fresh rolls to our much diminished bread basket. Turned out, he was the owner and the person responsible keeping this restaurant going after a family founder died some years ago. This is a family Italian restaurant that provides excellent food, very reasonable prices and pride that shines through as the owner is there, on the floor to greet you.
author: Peter B.

description:
Some friends took me here for my birthday. The food wasn't bad at all, but my pasta was a little overcooked -- a cardinal sin for an Italian restaurant. The decor is fine for what it is and the place has a nice feel to it.

With all of that said, there was one thing I really did not enjoy: our waiter. He was creepy as HELL. Flirting with the women at the table is fine, and I'll accept that as his schtick, but he just came off as a freak. He was one of those guys who makes eye contact, but then holds it for just a moment or two too long to be comfortable. He tried to joke a lot, but the only time he was funny was when he told us to come back anytime but Tuesday, because that's his day off... and that was funny for the wrong reasons.

With all that said, this place came highly recommended by a friend, I'd be more than willing to give this place another shot on a Tuesday (or in a different section). I'm sure it could earn a 4th star with a better waiter.

Your mileage may vary.
author: Mike M.

description:
I had to knock off stars because after a small fly found its way into my half-drunk glass of wine, they didn't bring me any more or take the charge off of the bill. I suppose it's not really their fault, but it's not mine either.

The food was delicious. I strongly recommend the eggplant appetizer. The waiter warned us about the bread being very hot when he brought it out. He wasn't kidding, it was steaming. I had gnocchi in aurora sauce (marinara and alfredo sauce mixed together) and my boyfriend had veal parmigiana.

It was my birthday and they turned down the lights, and played happy birthday over the restaurant's speaker system. I got a flan with a candle in the middle! It was tasty and gone very quickly. 

La Traviata could be regarded as a refuge in the middle of the neighborhood it's found in. It is quiet, clean and well maintained. The waiter was very attentive all through the meal and even hailed a cab for us before we left.
author: Monika V.

description:
Love this place!!!! This is what The City is all about right here!!!

Good food, EXCELENT service and drumroll please...PARKING on Mission St... no really you can park close even on fri/sat nite.

Same cool ass staff for years. Got questions or cant decide let them help you out.

I thought like me and ten other people knew about this spot, but i see you cant keep a good thing secret from you yelpers.

Oh yeah. had dinner there one night and an opera singer whose picture was on the wall was at the table next to us. Kinda cool 

This is
author: Scotty B.

description: incredible fresh bread and tasty pasta dishes! best Italian for the price in the mission
author: Amin S.

description:
I have to say I wasn't as bowled over as everyone else. We had the special house tortellini and the chicken "Beverly Sills" and both of them were VERY salty. I'm a person who tends to like salty foods, but this was a bit much even for me. The tortellini were also a bit overcooked. The consistency of the cream sauce was just perfect, if they could've only held off on some of that salt.

The Caesar salad had just the right amount of chopped up anchovies (and hence salt) but not enough garlic, and the cheese was ground (personally I prefer it shaved) and there were only two or three croutons.
author: Mike F.

description:
La Traviata is so close to my place that I relied on the Yelp reviews and picked it for a special dinner. The inside is charming - everything Yelp reviewers have said is true. The bread was divine and the wine service impeccable. I ordered the sauteed Basa and my friend had the prawns. His was terrific, mine was so boring and dry that even the lemon caper sauce couldn't bring it to life. The veggies were perfect. We had both the red and white sauce on the tortellini, and they were tasty. We did not order starters or salads, but it took almost 2 hours to get through dinner. There were perhaps 10 other tables being served, and I could not see a reason for the delays. That's a minus one star. There were also fruit flies landing on my food and wine - another minus.
The prices are fair, the people are well trained and hospitable, and I promise to come back again and give them another shot. This experience was a bit disappointing however.
author: OffToRio B.

description: I had the pleasure of eating here again and was less charmed by the place, which feels more old than cute now. The food portions are very generous but the quality is exceedingly average. It's not bad by any means, but not worth a special trip if you don't live nearby.
author: Ryan K.

description:
This restaurant is great for many reasons:

1. it's a nice change-up from the standard mexican fare in the neighborhood. 
2. the dim lighting and dark wood interior with wall-to-wall pictures of various Italian opera singers, makes me nostalgic for the East Coast.  
3. the service while not always the quickest is always impeccable.
4. the food is just fantastic! Since the Last Supper Club changed to Barretta, I missed getting eggplant parmagiana or tortellini.   La Traviatta offers these standard dishes along with unique ones.  I especially love the figs in balsamic reduction with feta salad! 
5. finally, the price can't be beat for what you get: non-pretentious, good food.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Ok, if I didn't live a couple blocks away this place would get 3 stars. However, the piping hot bread that comes to the table so soon after you sit down... I dream about that bread and the little butter golf balls that they serve. I'm glad I'm not an Atkins freak. And the bruschetta! For the love of everything-- it's perfection. (Coincidence that it's made from the same amazing bread they serve you at the table? Not so much.) But besides the bread just being good, they always seem to find fresh tomatoes for the bruschetta topping. How do they pull that off in the winter? Some things are better left as mysteries. The main courses are solid. I've never had a main course there that has changed my life, but I've never been disappointed either. 

The waitstaff-- must talk about them. Like I said, I've been a bunch because it's close and warm and cozy with decent food. I have always had the older, sweet Italian man take our order (must be part of the family) and he is always so lovely. But then, after a little wine, one of the younger waiters stops by our table and tells my husband how "bella" I am. And he doesn't leave. You know the whole gig about the stereotypical Italian waiter flirting with all of the women at the table-- it's fun, everyone knows what's going on, makes the girls giggle... This is just a touch more than that. Sort of like that friend who doesn't take non-verbal cues very well. But I don't care. I'll keep going back. The bread alone is enough to get me back there a couple times a month.
author: Ann F.

description:
Every time I think about this place my mouth waters.  I have a flashback from the last meal I had there.  
My boyfriend took me there on a rare rainy day because we both craved some good pasta.  Walking in we felt under dressed, it was family style Italian style and we felt welcome both by the staff and the other customers.  The Table was adorned with roses and candlelight. 
This is a true gem. 
The french bread was so light and buttery as if a block of butter was baked right into the loaf... All I can say is YUMMY!  
(ask to take some home, to warm the bread up without drying it out, wrap it in a damp paper towel and warm in the microwave for 15 mintues .  The moisture will stay in the bread not allowing it to dry out.)

All the pasta are home made.  Everyone must try the cheese tortellini, that with each bite you want to slowly enjoy every cream filling every tasty morsel is Devinne. I would call it Og.... isc but i think that of every dish i have tried there and nothing has come close. 

I'm getting ahead of myself for appetizer, must try the walnut, Gorgonzola cheese salad with a honey vinaigrette. Its truly refreshing and light, excellent partner for your main entree.   
Another dish that is a must try (again come here more than once you will not be disappointed!) i the Gnocchi, I have never had potato dumplings that melt in your mouth.  When you put one in your mouth you are consumed by the richness of the sauce on the outside but once you bite in you just taste the softness, salivating texture and mouthwatering scrumptious the potato dumplings will be.  Two distinct tastes with one bite!

You will get your money's worth with each delicious meal. It's not just a meal its an experience.  

This is a must try!
author: Jac J.

description:
This past Tuesday my friend and I were just out havin' some fun in our neighborhood .. started at the 3300 Club then International Club .. after that we realized.. FOOD IS NEEDED!  While walking down Mission towards our home we were trying to decide where to eat when "hey what about that little Italian place?".  So that's where we ended up.

We opened the door and stood there like a deer in headlights for a moment wondering if we were to be seated... when a gentleman from the kitchen waves us in with a big smile and points and says 'here sit'.  So we do.

Next it was the hot bread..menus and 'what would you like to drink?. We ordered the Barbera (forgot who by and vintage...but who cares) because it was deliciously gooood wine.  We ordered the appetizer special Stuff Portabello Mushroom and the Melon and Proscuitto then for our mains I ordered Al Funghi Pasta and my friend had the Gnocchi in Vodka Cream sauce.  If the restaurant had been quieter you would have heard the two girls at that table having multiple orgasms.  

Then it was dessert time...our friendly waiter suggested the Tiramisu and OMG...another orgasm or two was heard.  We gobbled that down in seconds and sat back to finish our wine when I said 'you have any Biscotti?'...and to our surprise our other friendly waitperson brought out a plate of, what seemed to be fresh baked, Biscotti. If it wasn't it could have been from just across the street at Dianda's (yummy bakery). After one more plate of Biscotti and our wine finally finished...we paid our bill, excitedly said over and over, THANKS THANKS THANKS .. that's the best Italian we've had in a long time.  

No more words needed except 'EAT AT LA TRAVIATA FOR THE FOOD, THE SERVICE  .. IT'S LIKE EATING AT A FAMILY'S HOUSE YOU'VE KNOWN ALL YOUR LIFE'.   : )
author: Diana C.

description:
Solid food, fresh and lots of it.

The decor is a bit blah, but the focus is on the food, where it should be.

Try the carbonera, it's delish.
author: Tony A.

description:
I had my birthday here and the service was horrible.

We made reservations but were seated an hour late, then it was almost another hour before they brought water and bread and took our orders.

My food was ok, but the gnocci tasted like it was boiled in dirty water.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
" In Mexico, we call the last drops of the wine 'the drops of happiness'. We always give them to the women because we don't want unhappy women"

These are the pearls of wisdom given to me at this fantastic italian restaurant in the middle of the mission. The fried Mozzarella is to die for as is the El Bocce Sangiovese wine. The only thing keeping this place from 5 stars is it's sub-par gnocchi. The waiters are great, the food is great, the atmosphere is a bit too "romantic" for me, but it's great kitsch if you like that sort of thing. I agree with the guy below me, don't bring your friends and over populate it, but definitely come by and eat their delicious food.
author: Jenni C.

description: been here about 4 times already in the last 2 months. I really enjoy the small, dimmed, comfortable atmosphere. Service is GREAT. I love everything on their menu and can't wait to try more. Their KNOCHI is the BEST knochi i have EVER had. I tell my friends, it literally MELTS in your mouth.. and everytime they try it, they say 'yea, you're right." hmmm hmmm good!
author: Sophie L.

description:
I have been eating there for years. It is a gem of the Mission. A family owned business and he servers are very friendly and accommodating . I have been there when it was so full you can't hear  and when it was so empty you can hear a pin drop. I love the food but it is a bit pricey  however they make the canolli fresh! 
I love the cheesy opera star photos plastered all over it reminds me of old school style. The servers really are awesome and yest service is slow but for Italian food and family dinners you want to be slow and take your time I stayed for 2 hours once and they never fussed at all... I guess if you are in a hurry don't eat there

I love that they aren't  trying to join the rat race of the hipster class that have wormed  their way into a once family area and made it a place to just shop and eat..(I am a bit bitter about mi Mission)
author: Kitty L.

description:
La Traviata is a gem that offers affodable, flavorful, robust pasta and dinners in a relaxing Italian-ish atmosphere. It feels like a location warp and a time warp, but not awkwardly so. They take a lot of pride in their restaurant. 

Food: The ceasar is tangy and good. The bread is freshly baked and actually quite light. This is a butter not olive oil place, and the butter comes in scooped out balls, just like at the dinner houses my parents used to take me to. There's a selection of meatless pasta which are very tasty (and meat ones, too, of course). The chicken dishes that you have to wait for are rather good, too, and we've tried both. They are very concerned that you order these on time. The one weakness we discovered is the gnocci; skip it here and go to Il Borgo or Capri for gnocci. 

Have not tried the desserts yet but the comp birthday Tiramisu is only so-so. 

I like the opera music as it's different, relaxing and not intrusive. I like all the kitshy photos. I like that we always have a waiter, who I think is French, at this Italian joint in the Mish. I've sat down when the place is mostly empty only to find it completely full later with people from 20 to 70 somethings,  including couples, groups, families.

And, miracle of mirales, we always find parking on Saturday nights within a block away.
author: Paris E.

description:
We walked in and were plesantly surprised. I had read the yelp reviews so I had decent expectations - tempered by the fact that I now live in California.

The decor was warm and inviting. My friend and I at once thought - perfect date place! The lighting was dim, but the restaurant still seemed family friendly. The bread was warm and delicious and the figs in our salad were wonderful. We started getting excited that we had finally found an edible Italian spot to help with our constant Jersey Italian food cravings. Then we got our entrees - they were ok but something seemed odd... then we realized it.. the red sauce on my pasta tastes just like chef boyardee! and your roast chicken.. well I could make that at home.. sigh.

Would I go back? Maybe... service was very nice, atmosphere was good.. its... california Italian.. what can you do?
author: Nors P.

description:
FOOD: 3 stars this visit /  5 stars previous visit
SERVICE: 4 STARS
I was a huge fan of this place years ago.  It was a family favorite.  But everyone moves away and next thing you know, it has been at least 7 years since my return.  All I could think of was the chicken a la cacciatore.  This is the #1 reason why I remember this place so fondly. 
Well, I didn't get to taste.  The menu says it takes 20 minutes 'till ready, but the waitress said it was more like an hour.  Huh?  Well, I didn't have an hour to spare.
Anyway, ordered the Alla Ricciarelli.  It was good, not super memorable.  My wife had the special, the cioppino and wasn't impressed.  Wine was what you would expect.  The tiramisu was also done right..
The staff, however, was excellent and accommodated a large group at the last minute, even though they were booked solid that Saturday night.  
And I still want to give them 4 stars because everything looks the same.  I will have to return one day for the cacciatore, hopefully not in 7 years.
If you have time, please try the chicken a la cacciatore and comment.
author: N H.

description: I'm not going to bore anyone with a long story of my life LOL this restaurant is amazing my BF & I eat here all the time it's one of the best Italian eats in San Francisco !! I order ( ai fungi ) & my bf gets ( puttanesca ) both really great !! Enjoy
author: C D.

description: I love La Traviata! You walk in and immediately get that family vibe. From the lighting to the staff to the photos and, of course, the amazing dishes this place is amazing. I got the putanesca this round and really tried hard to not overdo myself on the bread. So good! I always ask for oil/vinegar. Makes a big difference. Can't wait til next time.
author: Ash G.

description:
I love this place...good food, amazing service, great value in such a charming place!

I have dreams about the butter balls and fresh bread....and the eggplant Melanzane Imbotitte - OMG!!!!

I think I've had everything on the menu at some point and I've liked it all, John (the owner) has even made a couple special dishes for my friends birthday, that was unbelievable!

When you walk in to this place it is almost like you've been transported to your Italian grandma's house, with all of the pictures on the walls!  This is an amazing gem, that you shouldn't miss!
author: Rachel C.

description: A perfect date night. It was heavily misting outside and we wanted warm comfort food. This place was a perfect surprise in the midst of the hectic Mission - cozy, warm, and with absolutely delicious food. I have never had gnocchi like this in my life! The waiters are kind and attentive, and have a skill of making whatever you order sound like the best thing on the menu (though with the food we ate last night, it's hard to believe it could get any better). There's a reason they've been around for 38 years (can you imagine the things they've seen?). Try the Toscano Chianti from Tuscany if you love red wine. We'll be back!
author: Light E.

description: great food, friendly people. walking into the restaurant is like entering another world. it feels like you're stepping through a portal. picture frames of famous opera singers line the walls. candles and chandeliers softly illuminate the dark interior. the food was delicious, especially the panna cotta.
author: Marc H.

description: My favorite Italian place in the city!  Very romantic, priced well, excellent service and great food!!!  I've been several times and never been disappointed.
author: Hassan A.

description: Even amidst the plethora of taquerias, La Traviata still manages to be an unassuming, unpretentious Italian restaurant in the Mission.  The wall-to-wall framed photographs and paintings seem like a corny backdrop to the dim, intimate dining experience.  The proprietors are jovial and make you feel right at home.  The noise from an opera track and several groups of patrons remained at a low enough volume for conversations within our party to be easily heard.  But the most important element, the food, I thought to be average.  (I'm also not a huge fan of Italian, so take it for what it's worth.)
author: Marsha Z.

description:
The boyish Mr. D., who back in the day used to proclaim his disdain of foodie-ness (don't deny it, Dean, you once uttered the immortal words: "People who talk about food are boring.") brought me to this lovely, cozy little hole in the wall on Mission, saying "I think you might like it."  
Did I like it?
How could I not?
First star: ambiance...photos of opera stars and opera posters line the walls, the booths are super-comfortable and old-timey without being musty and dirty (the linens were spotless, which I love)
Second star; Service.  The waiters were as friendly as Dean had described, very warm and welcoming and accomodating, even when Dean got drunk and shouted abuse at them (okay, I exaggerate: Dean is always as polite as can be, but it was really funny when the waiter asked if he could help us with our wine choice and Dean said "No!  She knows what she's doing!" which made me feel all important and Italian and conoisseur-y (and then of course I picked the wrong wine and the patient waiter gave us a better suggestion). 
Third star, of course, was for the food, which was tasty and plentiful. My minestrone was, first of all, hot (thank you for providing the obvious, and not falling prey to that dumbing down of soups for fear of horrible litigious assholes who will sue you if they burn their tongues with the soup, like their mammas never told them to blow first--and getcha minds out of the gutter).
My entree, the sausage pasta (do I sense  a theme here?) was very yummy: the sausage had been crumbled and was dotted with fresh parsley and garlic...the pasta was appropriately chewy and dense, and the sauce was spicy and satisfying.
Dean loved his salmon en papillote, which looked magnificent (he offered me some but I was too busy stuffing my face with the pasta).
Fourth star was for being there with Dean, who is the most charming and loquacious of hosts (even though he told me his throat was hurting and that I'd have to do most of the talking, we ended up covering the gamut from love to politics to health to books to movies to life to crushes to bodies to people to gossip...and I must say that the intimate ambience of La Traviata helped fuel our non-stoppiness).
By the time we left the restaurant was packed with a very interesting assortment of people: old, young, oldstyle, newstyle.  I know that I'll always want to go back there and that should I ever move to SF it might even become "my restaurant."
Thanks to the handsome Mr. D for bringing me there, and hugs to the waiters and chefs at La Traviata for making it such a nice experience for me.
author: Valentina D.

description:
according to my boyfriend, this place is the real life version of the SNL skit featuring dana carvey and adam sandler repeating the line "you like-a the pepper?"

maybe it was the hilarious wait staff who was at our beck and call all evening, 

maybe it was the fact that they still had an enormous christmas tree and garland in the middle of the restaurant,

maybe it was how they turned all the lights out and played an old-time version of "happy birthday" FULL BLAST on the record player to commemorate the day of one guest's birth,

or maybe it was the unbelievably, AMAZING, delicious, homestyle-like-grandma-used-to-make italian food in the middle of the mission.

whatever it was, i love this place.
author: Natalie H.

description:
La Traviata is a tasty treat! This place is a gem. 
La Traviata in the MIssion is a sweet and simple gem of a restaurant! Quality food served with love and old school charm.
I went here with 2 friends for dinner. A place to go for a classy,fun time with friends or a cozy, private place with someone special. 

Although you can find more sophisticated and amazing food than La Traviata out there....the genuine care, attention and simple quality is what makes La Traviata stand out. The service was impeccable, sweet and humble. And so was the food! We ordered the delicious Salmon baked in a parchment envelope with a delectable sauce of aged balsamic, tomatoes and olives. The salmon melted in my mouth and the sauce was the perfect balance of tang and aged sweetness. I recommend the salmon, but truly I think anything you would order here would be excellent. The tiramisu is house made like everything else on the menu, and so so good.... authentic and fresh and just how you want tiramisu to be!
A little more about the service.... The two men that served us were attentive, professional and kind. They had a wonderful demeanor and an obvious dedication to good quality food and caring for their customers. Thanks La Traviata for creating such a nice evening!
author: Sacha G.

description:
WARNING:  This review is about to get all E. Coast authoritative on Italian-American restaurants. I understand this is off-putting to many, but honestly, I cannot take another review where the atmosphere is described as "50's kitch." (Oh, madonn!) Maybe that's what this place is reduced to in CA . . . and for you, I weep.

Listen bitches, I'm from Dirty Jersey, North Jersey to be exact, (and no, we do not say JOISEY, even motherfuckin Tony Soprano does not say JOISEY). I grew up eating at Italian-American (WHICH IS DISTINCT FROM ITALIAN)  restaurants in Newark and surrounding burbs. The kind of places where there is always at least one table of 6 morbidly obese men in ridiculous suits.  This means, that I get deeply concerned when someone in San Fran-fucking-cisco claims to have eaten at an authentic Italian-American place.   I will give some, very slight leeway if the place is in North Beach . . . because the good places generally get the food right,  but they almost ALWAYS screw up the atmosphere. You either get 1) red and white checked table cloths and "family style service" - I don't know what the fuck that is, but if my ass wants gnocchi and Jimmy wants Carbonara, and Mikey wants Veal Piccata, that just ain't going to cut it 2) ridiculously stylized places with perky waitstaff  and WAY, WAY too much light - i.e. Italian food goes to California (which by the way is fine when you're up for that, I am a big fan of the Delfina's of the world, but when the Italian uncles are in town I tend to Identify these places as Italian-California or the better ones "Italian -Italy Coastal"  but NEVER would I call any of these places Italian-American. 

La Traviata on the other hand, gets it right, down to the fake single rose on all the tables.  It has a cave like layout and a sitting area which separated from the dinning room by a perfectly tacky stained glass window set in wood. Its white table cloth (of course!), and  the service is perfect:  two man tag team, one older and one younger (son, brother, cousin?), both tremendously gracious in that slightly overstated way.  I'd have given the place five stars before I ate a thing.  I was home.

Some notes on Italian-AMERICAN food, because a few people have missed this distinction (and hey you just might not like it, and that's cool), there is absolutely no subtlety involved. it should be heavy garlic on garlic and the portions should be large (if you have to add salt, they've done soemthing wrong). . . what is unacceptable in this medium is overcooked pasta, bland sauces, crappy seafood and a holier than thou attitude. SO, they lost a star on my Gnocchi, it wasn't firm enough.  The Bruchetta was very good, my date's pasta did not disappoint, (I tend not to comment on Caprese unless something goes wrong because I think that's pretty hard to screw up - and they didn't).  The tiramasu was surprisingly good (I always order tiramasu with trepidation because I've seen it interpreted in some bizarre ways). 

I will absolutely go back.  For one app, one salad,  two pastas, a bottle  of wine, desert and a glass of 20yr port with tip it was around $100 - which is about right.
author: Jen A.

description: I don't give 5 star reviews. If this place were a person, it would be that quirky little guy who is so happy with just who he is that everyone likes him.
